content.text: Black.
Nicole, early 30’s, appears out of the dark.

dialogue: She makes people feel comfortable about even embarrassing things.

content.text: We remain CLOSE on her face in shadow. She’s very still and very serious.

dialogue: She really listens when someone is talking...

content.text: Her coming out of a subway. A young “funny” ASPCA solicitor stops her.

dialogue: Hey, you look like you care about animals?
...sometimes she listens TOO much, for too long-- She’s a good citizen.

content.text: The kid launches into his pitch. She listens intently and starts writing down her phone number.

dialogue: She always knows the right thing to do when it comes to difficult family shit.

content.text: Charlie is sulking. A hand holds out a phone.
He reluctantly grabs the phone.

dialogue: I get stuck in my ways and she knows when to push me and when to leave me alone.

content.text: She cuts their son, (8 years old) Henry’s hair. We see Charlie sweeping up.
Cuts Charlie’s hair. We see the kid sweeping up.
Cuts her own in the mirror. Charlie and the kid play in the background.
She sweeps up her own hair.

dialogue: She’s always inexplicably brewing a cup of tea that she doesn’t drink.

content.text: A kettle whistles.
STILL LIFES of mugs of tea on window sills, bookshelves, Henry’s toy shelf, on the floor...
All the kitchen cabinets are open. Charlie closing drawers, picking up shoes. Charlie hitting his head on the corner of an open cabinet.

dialogue: And it’s not easy for her to put away a sock, or close a cabinet, or do a dish, but she tries for me.

content.text: A framed PHOTO of Nicole, Sandra (her mom) and Cassie (her sister) standing in the front lawn of a Hollywood home. Nicole is pretending to step on the reclining dog.

dialogue: Nicole grew up in LA around actors and directors and movies and TV and is very close to her mother, Sandra, and, Cassie, her sister.

content.text: Charlie rips open a present. It’s a trumpet.

dialogue: Nicole gives great presents. She is a mother who plays -- really plays -- she never steps off playing or says it’s too much
(and it must be too much some of the time)

content.text: She and Henry play in the park with Star Wars figures. The kid makes high pitched sounds for the fights.

dialogue: He’s dead but you can use this guy.

content.text: Nicole, Charlie and Henry are playing Monopoly.

dialogue: Goddammit! I was just IN jail!

content.text: Henry and Charlie look at each other and laugh.

dialogue: Do NOT laugh at me. I’m serious. Do NOT LAUGH AT ME!

content.text: Nicole is reading to Henry in bed. She’s falling asleep while reading, but still managing to read.

dialogue: She’s a great dancer. Infectious. She makes me wish I could dance.

content.text: Nicole putting on a song and getting people to dance at a cast party.

dialogue: She always says when she doesn’t know something or hasn’t read a book or seen a film or a play
(whereas I fake it or say something like, “I haven’t seen it in a while.”)
She keeps the fridge over-full. No one is ever hungry in our house. She can drive a stick.

content.text: Charlie’s trying to open a jar of pickles. He struggles. He knocks it on a table. Grabs a dish towel and tries it that way. No luck.

dialogue: She’s amazing at opening jars because of her strong arms, which I’ve always found very sexy.

content.text: On TV, a younger Nicole (acting in a movie) is part of a raucous college party.
NICOLE IN THE MOVIE You might as well get what you paid for!
She grabs her shirt and lifts it-- We PAUSE mid-lift before it comes off.

dialogue: She’s brave. After that movie, All Over The Girl, she could have stayed in LA and been a movie star, but she gave that up to do theater with me in New York.

content.text: We’re back to the first image of her face in half-shadow. Suddenly she walks forward and into a spotlight.

dialogue: My crazy ideas are her favorite things to figure out how to execute.

content.text: She walks across the floor and climbs (scales like a rock- face) the body of a male actor.

dialogue: Try it crawling but also standing.

content.text: We see that she’s on a stage, rehearsing for a play.
CLOSE on Charlie, early 30’s, in deep thought. A warm yellow glow on his face.

dialogue: What I love about Charlie... Charlie is undaunted. He never lets other people’s opinions or any set-backs keep him from what he wants to do.

content.text: Charlie eats sloppily with Henry at a pizza place. He suddenly stands up and walks around to Henry’s side. He asks Henry to raise his arms. He lifts Henry’s sweater up over his arms and turns it around to face the right way.

dialogue: Charlie eats like he’s trying to get it over with and like there won’t be enough food for everyone. A sandwich is to be strangled while devoured. But he’s incredibly neat and I rely on him to keep things in order.

content.text: Nicole is reading in a room. All the lights go out. She looks up. Charlie is at the switch.
He turns them back on.

dialogue: He doesn’t look in the mirror too often. He cries easily in movies.

content.text: He and Henry exit a movie theater. Both of them are crying.

dialogue: Me too. I wonder if it was the same four.
He is very self-sufficient -- he can darn a sock and cook himself dinner and iron a shirt.

content.text: He’s cooking - it’s elaborate. There are a lot of pots, a lot of steam. Henry is “helping.”

dialogue: (which I feel like I always do)

content.text: Nicole is raging about something.

dialogue: Charlie takes all of my moods steadily, he doesn’t give in to them or make me feel bad about them. He’s a great dresser, he never looks embarrassing which is hard for a man.

content.text: Charlie is serving in a tennis game.
He double faults.
Henry walks into their bedroom and taps Charlie on the shoulder until he wakes up.

dialogue: He loves being a dad, he loves all the things you’re supposed to hate, like the tantrums, the waking up at night.

content.text: He puts Henry back to sleep. Henry doesn’t want to sleep. They compromise with Charlie sleeping on the floor. Then Henry climbing down and sleeping with him on the floor. Then Charlie slipping out and getting into the bed. Then the kid getting into the bed with him.

dialogue: It’s almost annoying how much he likes it, but then it’s mostly nice.

content.text: He and Henry reading on the subway. The doors close. The train lurches forward. Charlie looks up suddenly.

dialogue: He disappears into his own world. He and Henry are alike in that way.
He can tell people they have food in their teeth or on their face in a way that doesn’t make them feel bad.

content.text: Nicole, from across a table picks something from between her teeth, she looks back up at Charlie who is off-camera, and smiles. It’s still there. She starts digging for it again.

dialogue: Charlie is self-made -- his parents -- I only met them once -- but he told me there was a lot of alcohol and some violence in his childhood.

content.text: Henry plays on the floor. Charlie leads a meeting with his set decorator and Nicole and the stage manager around a big table. They reference a model of the stage set.

dialogue: He moved to New York from Indiana with no safety net and now he’s more a New Yorker than any New Yorker.

content.text: Charlie is passing out coffees to all the actors and crew members of their theater at the beginning of a rehearsal. He’s gotten everyone’s drink right, and bought them all himself.

dialogue: He’s brilliant at creating family out of whoever is around.
I made sure they used the right almond milk--
With the theatre company he cast a spell that made everyone feel included. No one, not even an intern was unimportant. He could remember all the inside jokes.
And where do YOU go when it’s windy?!

content.text: We RETURN to the close-up of Charlie. He sits in the back of an empty theater taking notes, the small yellow reading light illuminating his face. He watches Nicole, in rehearsal, climb up onto the actor as she did earlier.
Nicole, up almost atop the actor’s head, turns to him with a look that asks, “Was that OK?” Charlie nods.
CLOSE on a sheet of paper: We can see written everything we just heard.
Nicole, no make-up, in a baggy sweatshirt and jeans, sits in a chair, not saying a word, staring at a piece of paper in her lap.

dialogue: I’m not going to read this out loud.
I don’t like what I wrote.

content.text: We see now that she and Charlie are sitting in two adjacent chairs in an office on the Upper West Side. A male
tightly cross-legged, facing them.

dialogue: As we mediate your separation and eventual divorce, things can become quite contentious, so I like to begin with a note of positivity. For the people I work with to remember why they got married in the first place. And so, that as you come apart, you’re reminded that this is a person you had great feeling for and maybe still do in many ways--
I’ll read mine. I like what I wrote.
For it to really work, you both have to read--
She always says I can’t write. But I think mine is pretty good.
Nicole, maybe you’ll change your mind once you hear Charlie’s.
I don’t want to hear Charlie’s.
That’s right, that’s the very first step in this process.

content.text: Nicole stands up, suddenly furious.

dialogue: Well, I think I’ll go if you two are just going to sit around and suck each other’s dicks!

content.text: A hubbub of protests then:

Audience members watch, rapt. Nicole is on-stage in a red dress. A black and white video of her face projected on either side of her. On stage, she delivers her lines in an almost life-less way while the video Nicole is very animated and emotional.
Charlie sits in the back of the theatre--she can’t see his face, but she knows where he is.
She continues speaking, looking into the audience when several bodies approach her, turn her to her side and carry her off like a stiff rolled-up rug.
Charlie sees her looking and is sad and disturbed and stops writing his notes for a moment.
Behind her, a portal opens up, the stage is awash in red light and the company members carry her through the door.

Closing night party. The whole company is there celebrating, this is clearly their spot. There’s a piano, and names are pulled from a bowl and people take turns singing. Investors mingle as well, notable for the disobedient air of people who shouldn’t be “downtown.”

A woman, 30’s, Mary Ann, also the stage manager (we saw her earlier in rehearsals), sits in a booth with the costume designer, Donna, 40’s. She looks over at Charlie in a booth in the corner, surrounded by members of the troupe. He works on a beer and makes more notes in a book.

dialogue: Do you think I can go over there now?

content.text: Donna, turns and we SWING OVER to: Nicole, on the other side of the room at a table flanked by other members of the cast and crew.
On Charlie’s end of the room, Frank, an older actor, carries on with Terry, a younger one.

dialogue: ...Charlie gave me the note - but it’s really for you: he told me to pick up my cues.
Acting is reacting - I’m responding to you and you’re slowing ME down.
...hey, hello, Frank - it’s closing night, you know, we’re done?!

content.text: They all cheers and laugh.

dialogue: ...but we’ll have to restage it anyway!
...and you know Charlie, it’s never done, he never finishes.

content.text: They all laugh, but they’re excited, it’s big. Charlie, still looking at his notes, reaches out and pats the actor’s leg affectionately. Terry, gets up--
--and makes his way across the room passing other company members and snippets of conversation.

dialogue: ...that’s why it seems wrong to take over for Nicole - the role is hers! And what if her pilot doesn’t go, she’ll come back from LA and want the part back, right?
Something like 100 percent of pilots don’t get picked up.
It can’t be 100 percent. There would never be any shows.
No, but statistically, it’s true. The probability is zero. It’s one of those things.
You don’t think Charlie and Nicole will ever get back together?
No, this time it’s really over.
...I feel like MY parents are splitting up.
It’s always been “Charlie and Nicole.” It just doesn’t sound right any other way.

content.text: Terry passes Mary Ann and Donna who still watch Charlie.
Terry arrives at the booth at the other end of the room where Nicole and her group are camped together.
ANOTHER ACTOR (shaking her head) He still giving notes?

dialogue: You’re lucky, Nic, I wish I was going to LA. You can have space in LA. There’s no SPACE here.

content.text: Nicole looks across the restaurant and catches Charlie’s eye. He mouths “hi” and she nods. Is it nice?

Frank stands and makes a toast to Charlie and Nicole and the move to Broadway (”The Main Stem”) and how much they’ll miss Nicole and then makes it about him returning to Broadway with the young turks. In 1968, he was the young turk.

dialogue: Winning your first Tony at 27-- which I did--messes with your head. I was just a baby! Elia Kazan came backstage on opening night elbowing Mike Nichols into a corner. Mike, who I later turned down twice, a big regret of mine...

content.text: During the speech, Mary Ann, the stage manager, suddenly rises (we can see Donna making protestations) and makes her approach to Charlie’s corner, whispering something in his ear.

dialogue: I wanted to make sure that I have all your notes down so I can compile them into the master list for when we move into the new theater...

content.text: Nicole, clocking this, abruptly stands. Charlie sees her rise and does the same.
Riding home across the Manhattan Bridge. Nicole sits on the mostly empty bench gazing out the window.
Although there are available seats, Charlie stands and leans against the doors.
She and Charlie enter and relieve a young babysitter who for some reason is buttoning her pants up and looks a little ashamed.

dialogue: Oh hey, I didn’t expect you guys until late.
Good, good. He went to bed on time, no fuss. I read him some of Cricket in Times Square...
God, you guys are so attractive.
Shit, sorry. I didn’t stop that from being said.

content.text: Nicole goes back and checks on Henry--

dialogue: Ha! No it’s okay. I’ll pay you for the whole time, we decided to come home early.
Hey, thanks! And also the travel time to Greenpoint--

content.text: She stumbles on something. It’s his little suitcase, open on the floor--toys crammed into it. He’s sleeping soundly, all twisted up in his superhero sheets. He uses a well- worn white bear as a pillow. She fixes his sheets.

The Babysitter is gone and Charlie is setting up the couch as his bed. He surveys the room while he reflexively fiddles with a small X-Acto knife on his key chain. We CUT QUICKLY between objects (the clicking sound of the knife as a soundtrack): Books, a chair, table, lamp, a TV which turns on, painting, photos... Objects from their life together. (Mugs of tea rest beside some of these objects.)
A book on a table.
Nicole retrieves the book and heads back to the bedroom. Charlie’s voice stops her:

dialogue: It’s not always going to be like this, it’s going to get better.

content.text: Nicole nods.

dialogue: If you don’t like that mediator, we’ll find another one--
We might not need a mediator, we’ll just split everything anyway, I don’t care--
You can have most of it.
We’ll get apartments near each other, make it easier for Henry--
We’ll figure it out. We want the same things.

content.text: Nicole meets Charlie’s eye. He hesitates.

dialogue: In the meantime, the pilot will be fun for you.
You don’t think it’s bad, do you?
I don’t ever watch TV so, you know, I can’t tell...

content.text: Nicole glances over at the TV which is on.

dialogue: I told Henry I’ll come out to LA in two weeks to see him.

content.text: Nicole nods. Charlie looks down at his notebook. Looks back up at Nicole.
Nicole turns, and then turns back.

dialogue: I can tell you want to give me a note.
No, I don’t... Yeah, I mean, yes I do. But I guess, I guess it doesn’t matter now. You won’t be with the show anymore. It’s stupid.
You’re not going to be able to go to sleep until you tell me.
Well, yes, okay, but just because saying it out loud might help me remember it for later.
So - there were two things - I thought your posture at the top of scene seven was still too dignified...
--and then at the end, I could tell that you were pushing for the emotion--
--you know I can’t cry on stage and I know you don’t like when I fake it, but I thought maybe it would come tonight. But it didn’t...

content.text: He flips through the notebook. Silence.

dialogue: That’s all I had. Thanks for indulging me.

content.text: She starts crying as soon as she turns away from him. We MOVE with her as she cries through the apartment to their bedroom. She trips briefly on one of her suitcases also lying on the floor open and half-packed. She removes her shoes, but not her clothes, and gets into bed, crying.
Fade to Black.
A curtain flies open revealing a rich blue sky and swaying palm trees. The light is painfully bright. We hear a female voice lightly singing:

dialogue: “This is the day, this is the day...”

content.text: Nicole opens her eyes which are crusted with mascara and tears. Her mother, Sandra, 60’s, violently opens the curtains, loudly closes drawers and doors.
We’re in LA.

dialogue: “That the Lord has made, that the Lord has made...”

content.text: Nicole rolls over. Henry, yawning, lies next to her in the bed.

dialogue: “Let us rejoice, let us rejoice. And be glad in it and be glad in it...”

content.text: This is her childhood bedroom in her mom’s house. There are old magazines (Cosmo, Seventeen, Teen Vogue, Maxim) with photos of Nicole. An MTV Best Kiss award. There is “Teenage Nicole” and “Adult Nicole” all mashed up together, and both Nicole’s are messy.
Nicole presses her face into the pillow.

dialogue: You can’t make home too nice, otherwise your children will never leave--

content.text: Nicole whispers to Henry.

dialogue: What do you want to do today?
Hang out and relax with you.
No relaxing! Nicole has a hair and make-up test and Henry, we got you into Fairy Camp with the cousins.
Cassie says everyone likes Fairy Camp and I think this is true.

content.text: Sandra kisses Henry on the head.

dialogue: Henry, go make your mom some coffee like I taught you--
Mom, wait till you taste my coffee.

content.text: Henry walks off, hair sticking up. Sandra fluffs the pillows, retrieving Henry’s white bear.

dialogue: Do you always sleep together? Even in New York?
It’s just for now, while we go through this transition. Shit, don’t tell Charlie when he gets here -- he hates co-sleeping.

content.text: Nicole climbs out of bed. Her pillow is stained with black eye make-up.

dialogue: Well, I have to say, I agree with Charlie.

content.text: Nicole walks toward the bathroom, Sandra behind her--

dialogue: It’s as if you’ve exploded into this room.

content.text: --and into the bathroom, her mother follows her inside.

dialogue: I can do this part alone?

content.text: Sandra leans against the sink, Nicole shrugs and lets her - how can she stop her now?

dialogue: As long as you’re in my house, wake up is at 6:30 AM. And until you know what you want to do, we’re going to do what I like to do.
I can’t just go from what Charlie wanted to do to what you want to do.

content.text: Nicole finishes, flushes and starts washing her hands.

dialogue: Even though I’m sixty-four and have a dead gay husband, I manage to get up everyday and live my life and feel pretty good about myself so maybe your Mom knows a thing or two.

content.text: Nicole heads out of the room and down the main staircase. Her mom following her, of course.

dialogue: You know what I would do?
When Charlie gets here, I would whisk him off to Palm Springs? That’s what your father and I did whenever we hit a speed bump--
Didn’t you walk in on Dad blowing the porter in Palm Springs?
And I always regretted getting so upset about it.
Charlie and I are getting a divorce, Mom. There’s nothing for us in Palm Springs.
YOU NEED TO WASH YOUR FACE BEFORE YOU GO TO SLEEP.

content.text: They both enter the kitchen. Henry has made a giant mess with the coffee, and he’s trying to press down on a French Press coffee maker.

dialogue: When Daddy gets here maybe we can all go on the Jaws ride--
Or I can go once with you and once with Daddy because I wouldn’t mind going twice anyway--
Did you know Universal Studios is where I did my first screen test--
No, we’ll all go together, sweetheart.

content.text: Henry presents his mom a cup of coffee.

dialogue: On the plane, I re-read the pilot as if I were Charlie reading it and I started to think it’s just bad.
My agent says it’s “one to watch.”

content.text: She sips her coffee.

dialogue: This coffee IS good. Thank you.
What if Charlie’s on Broadway with the play I brought him--which I originated and I’m just doing bad TV.
It doesn’t matter. Everyone is only impressed when they see someone on TV.

content.text: Nicole is standing in front of a camera in a hair/makeup/wardrobe test. She’s barefoot in a nightgown with some kind of red mask being applied to her face. We hear voices (that she can’t) murmuring near the monitor.
Nicole holds what looks like a blue, foam football and stares combatively at the camera. Hands enter frame, adjusting her hair, swapping out the masks.

dialogue: Where’s she been for the past ten years? MALE PRODUCER

content.text: Doing weird theater in New She looks great. York.
No one answers. We hear bits of side-conversations about a book club book they’re all reading.

dialogue: Downtown shit. I saw one. It rained on stage.
It was good. Edgy. Directed by her husband. Supposedly very controlling.
Can she move her hand? It’s going to be hard to roto the hair in on the baby around her fingers--
Can you move your hand further down the baby?
What do you mean? Like down here?
I’d need to support his head.
No, no, support the head, of course, just try to do it from the shoulders?

content.text: She hesitantly slides her hand down the blue football.

dialogue: I can’t hold a baby like this.

content.text: FEMALE PRODUCER (O.S.) EFFECTS GUY (O.S.) She’s right, that’s going to Just so you know, we can look weird. TOTALLY do it, it’s just going to take time and money and mean less hair.
A handsome, bearded and tatted grip, 30’s, Pablo, enters frame with a white bounce board, holding it up to her.

dialogue: So we can see your pretty face. And not ours.
Ha. You should have seen me before the plants invaded.
I say that with respect. I was raised by two mothers.
Can you lower the board please, Pablo?

content.text: The grip lowers the bounce board then raises it directly in front of Nicole’s face, then lowers it, being cute.
Nicole smiles. A hand removes her mask and applies another.

dialogue: Why is there always a flirty grip.

content.text: Pablo finally places the board in the proper position.

dialogue: I can do ANYTHING you want, but we’ll need to have her two hours before call every day we work with the plants--

content.text: Someone walks through the shot carrying an enormous plant arm.

dialogue: She has to know how to hold a baby. Later after she kills Donny, she becomes this sort of earth mother for the plant community and that won’t make sense if we think she’s a bad mother to her own kid. MAKE-UP ARTIST

content.text: She kills Donny? That’s a secret. We didn’t give the crew those pages.

dialogue: You don’t want her to appear unsympathetic this early in the show, do you? MAKE-UP ARTIST

content.text: Does Donny know? She’s right.

dialogue: Also, why does she kill Donny anyway?

content.text: Nicole marches across the soundstage, still in the nightgown, now wearing Uggs, followed by the male (Dennis) and female (Carol) producers, both 50’s. He wears all denim. She’s in fitted jeans, and a white blazer. There’s also a cadre of hair and make-up and wardrobe people.

dialogue: Must be nice to get out of New York. Our daughter, Mia is at NYU living in a shoe box--
She’s says it went up to a hundred and four the other day--
We’re just so excited to have you.
We’re going for an early aughts aesthetic — so having your presence nails that. MAKE-UP ARTIST What signifies early aughts?

content.text: They go outside, the bright LA light hitting their eyes. Everyone puts on sunglasses.

dialogue: Into The Girl was on TV--
--or streaming or something and you are fucking HOT in that movie.
Fuck it, I speak my mind!
We’re not allowing our son to see it.
This is Carter Mitchum, he’s a futurist at UCLA who’s consulting on all the environmental stuff for the show.

content.text: Carter, 30’s, has been politely following behind. He reaches forward to shake her hand.
Nicole laughs. She’s handed another nightgown by the wardrobe assistant. “For when you’re on the mother ship.”

dialogue: This pilot WILL go. Get ready to move back to LA!
And listen: everything you were saying back there was absolutely right--
Except no one knows we’re killing Donny. Including Donny.
If she’s a bad mom, we’ll lose the audience.
Oh...good, you know, I just thought-
Let us know if you’d like to be part of our writer’s room -- I bet you’d be really helpful.
Or I could direct? Sorry, maybe that sounds crazy.
No, yeah... Do you have a reel?
No, because I’ve never done it. I mean, I watched my husband do it for years...
Almost ex-husband? What’s the opposite of fiance?
We’ll talk to your agents about it.
At our theater, I always wanted to direct and Charlie would say something like “The next one!” But he was always the director and there never was a next one.
But I don’t know, maybe there would have been if we stayed married. You know, I don’t know.

content.text: Nicole turns away, embarrassed. The Female Producer has been watching her, while the Male Producer is just texting like a motherfucker.
Nicole enters the cramped space and realizes the Female Producer is right behind her. Nicole tries to busy herself.

dialogue: I’m going to give you a number.
Oh...OK. Is it a therapist? I have a therapist. Well, she’s my mom’s therapist. We share her.
She’s a lawyer, she represented me when I left Dennis.
And you still work together? That’s nice.
Oh, no, he’s a fucking cocksucker. Nora got me half of this project in the settlement.
We talked about doing it without lawyers.
You think that, but you won’t...
My sister made me meet a bunch of them already, I just HATED them.
Call Nora. She saved my life.
I’m sorry I look so schleppy.

content.text: Nora Fanshaw, 40’s, looks amazing and elegant. Today she is in tight designer jeans, a YSL blazer, red pumps and full make-up.

Nicole, in old jeans and a button-down, sits on a comfortable, stylish couch, a Moroccan rug on the floor--in an office that looks like a suite at a W Hotel. A sheepskin throw, fresh flowers on the coffee table.

dialogue: I had an event at my kid’s school.

content.text: Nicole grows suddenly self-conscious about what she’s wearing.

dialogue: Let me get this out of the way, I think you’re a wonderful actress.
I loved All Over The Girl but the theater stuff too.
I was in New York last year for my book -- which, remind me to give you a copy -- and my publisher took me.
He is. They’re moving it to Broadway. Without me of course.
He was lucky to have you.
While I’m making a show about a plant invasion.

content.text: Having been asked that question at that moment in that way, does something to her. Tears run down Nicole’s cheeks.
Nora kicks off her shoes and tucks them under her feet. She rises, grabs a box of tissues and curls up next to Nicole on the couch.
Nicole takes a tissue and she and Nora meet eyes. It feels intimate and safe.

dialogue: You take some breaths. And while you do, I’m going to tell you about myself.

content.text: She texts something to someone and then very deliberately puts her phone down on the table. Nora puts her hand on Nicole’s leg. She talks to her like a good girlfriend.

dialogue: If you should choose to hire me, I will work tirelessly for you and am always available by phone or text, EXCEPT when I’m with my kids. I insist on doing drop-off and pick-up at school every day.

content.text: An assistant enters with a tray that has green tea and cookies. Nicole starts eating the cookies, Nora does not.

dialogue: I’ve been through this myself so I know how it feels.
Yes. I have a kid from my ex who was a narcissistic artist and verbally abusive. I’m now with a great boyfriend, who lives in Malibu.
No, of course not, but they ravish you with attention in the beginning and then once we have babies, we become the mom and they get sick of us.

content.text: Nicole nods.

dialogue: Where do you want live now, doll?
Well, I’m here now, obviously, and I don’t know if this show will be picked up, but... it feels like home... it is home. It’s the only home I’ve known without Charlie.

content.text: Nicole likes hearing this affirmation, but then hesitates.

dialogue: Charlie won’t want to do that. He hates LA.
We’re interested in what YOU want to do. Sounds to me like you did your time in New York. He can do some time here, no?
He always said we would, but we never did.
Henry is eight. He likes LA, but I don’t know if it’s fair to him...
It sounds like a wonderful childhood to me: the first half New York and the second half in LA.

content.text: Nicole processes this.

dialogue: I want you to listen to me, what you’re doing is an act of HOPE. Do you understand that?
You’re saying, I want something better for myself.
And this, right now, is the worst time. It will only get better. Wasn’t it Tom Petty who said the waiting is the hardest part?
I represented his wife in their divorce, I got her half of that song.
Oh, I don’t want money or anything, he doesn’t have money anyway, he puts it all back into the theater-- I used to think he gave TOO much away. I just want it to be over.
Of course you do. But we can do both.
I just worry... You know we weren’t going to even use lawyers so...I don’t want to be too aggressive. I’d like to stay friends.
Don’t worry, we’ll do it as gently as possible.
Now, can you tell me a little bit more about what’s going on? Because part of what we’re going to do together is tell your STORY.

content.text: Nicole wipes her eyes for the millionth time. She stands and grabs a tissue from the table. She takes a deep breath.

dialogue: It’s difficult to articulate. Sorry. It’s like I know why I’m doing this but I don’t know too. It’s not as simple as not being in love anymore.
I understand. Why don’t you start at the beginning, wherever that is for you.

content.text: And Nicole begins. As she talks she finds her voice and gains momentum and she starts to feel better, the tears start to dry up and she becomes more powerful, more herself.

dialogue: Well, I was engaged to Ben, you know, and living in LA and I felt like “Yes, I want to make movies and marry Ben” - Jesus I was only nineteen or twenty, I’ve never felt older in my whole life - But if I was honest with myself, there was a small part of me that felt dead, or dead-ish, but you tell yourself “no one is perfect, no relationship is perfect.”
Isn’t it? It’s the Manuka honey.
Anyway, you were asking about Charlie. So yes, so I was happy with Ben, but aware of the deadness.

And then I went to New York to meet a director for a space movie, but one where they take space seriously. Sex trafficking in space. It was political, or they wanted us to think it was. It was actually just fulfilling the same need certain fucked up porn does. Anyway, while I was there, the producer invited me to a play. It was in someone’s living room with all the lights on and like nothing I’d ever seen before. A strange, surreal dystopian story. So well acted and one of the actors was this big shaggy bear who played all his lines looking directly at me which I knew couldn’t be really the case, but it felt that way, and of course later I learned that it was.
The cookies are really great too.
I’ll give you some to take home.

Afterwards, I was introduced to the cast and this bear turned out to also be the director. He didn’t really know who I was - or he did, or he figured it out later - and that was it. He started talking to me. And I talked back - and the dead part wasn’t dead, it was just in a coma. And it was better than sex, the talking. Although the sex was also like the talking... everything is like everything in a relationship, do you find that? ... We spent the whole night and next day together, and I just... never left. And to be honest, all the problems were there in the beginning, too. I just went along with him in his life because it felt so damn good to feel myself alive. In the beginning I was the actress, the star, so that felt like something. People came to see me, at first.

But then the farther away I got from that and the more the theatre company got acclaim, I had less and less weight. I became “Who?” “Oh you remember, that actress who was in that thing that time.” And he was the draw. And that would have been fine, but...I got smaller. I realized that I didn’t really ever come alive for myself, I was just feeding his aliveness. He was so smart and creative, it didn’t matter. I would tell him things at home, in private, and then they would work their way into public conversation, into his work and for a while that felt like enough. I was just so flattered that someone like him would find an idea of mine worth using or a comment of mine worth repeating. And then I got pregnant. And I thought “having a baby will be ours, really ours, and it will also really be mine” and he was so excited. And it was nice for a while. But kids... they belong to themselves. Like the instant they leave your body, it’s just a process of going away from you. And I didn’t belong to myself. It was stupid stuff and big stuff-- All of the furniture in our house was his taste. I wasn’t even sure what my taste was anymore because I’d never been asked to use it. I didn’t even pick our apartment, I just moved into his. I made noises about wanting to move back to LA, but it came to nothing. We’d come here on holidays because he liked my family, but whenever I suggested we do a year or something, he’d put me off. It would be so weird if he had turned to me and said “And what do you want to do today?” I watched that long documentary about George Harrison and I thought “just own it, own it like George Harrison’s wife. Being a wife and mother is enough.” And then I realized I couldn’t remember her name.

So this pilot came along, and it shot in LA and it paid so much and it was like there was a little life- line thrown to me “Here is a bit of earth that’s yours.” And I was embarrassed about it in front of him, but also, it felt like “this is who I am, this is what I’m worth and it’s stupid, but at least it’s mine.” And if he had taken me in a big hug and said “Baby, I’m so excited for your adventure and of course I want you to have your own piece of earth” then we might not be getting divorced. But he made fun of it. And was jealous, like he is. BUT then he realized about the money and told me I could funnel it back into the theatre company. And that’s when I realized that he truly didn’t see me. He didn’t see me as something separate from him. And I asked him to say my phone number. And he didn’t know it. So I left.

content.text: Nora wipes a ink-stained tear from Nicole’s cheek and hugs her.

dialogue: I think Charlie also slept with Mary Ann, the stage manager.

content.text: Cassie husband, Sam and their kids, Jules and Molly, play Monopoly with Henry in the den. Henry has trouble reading the Chance card. Sam helps him with it.

dialogue: But I want to keep my money.

content.text: CLOSE on a manilla envelope with Charlie’s name on it and
and Sandra are preparing. They’re all drinking wine and drinking it too fast.

dialogue: So, Cassie, you’re going to hand him the envelope--
Why do I have to do it?
Because Nicole is very good at getting people to do things for her--
I wiped her butt until she was nine years old. She’s very seductive that way.
No. Mom. Legally I can’t be the one who serves him.
But still this is true what I’m saying.
Do I have to actually hand him the envelope?
Yes, but I’m going to tell him in advance that they’re divorce papers. Nora says it doesn’t have to be so formal.

content.text: Nicole finishes what’s in her glass and pours herself more.

dialogue: He’s in the living room playing with Jules and Molly.
Let’s get them upstairs. So, I’ll tell Charlie what’s happening and Cassie, you can then hand him the envelope--
What do you mean, like take it back?
In case we change our minds.
I’m not going to change my mind.
I know, but maybe just to know in case I do something wrong--
Or we all just feel too bad for him.
Now you’re both just making ME feel bad about it, OK.
We all are. And we LOVE Charlie.
You have to STOP loving him, Mom. You can’t be his friend anymore.
Charlie and I have our own relationship independent of your marriage just like I’m friends with Cassie’s ex, Jeff--
He still wants his camera back by the way.
Listen, nothing can be independent of our marriage right now. I can’t believe I have to explain this to you. Just be on MY side, OK?
Just let me practice a few times. I was never a good auditioner.
It’s just my palms are so perspired.
Sweetie, you’re blotting the envelope. Maybe Nicole should play you.
Did you really just say that???
We don’t need to practice it. It’s not a performance!

content.text: Sandra is working on opening a bottle of wine.

dialogue: Did we finish the other one already?

content.text: Outside, a car door closes, they all jump. Cassie even screams. Nicole snaps into action.

dialogue: OK, let me get it. You both go in the other room. Cassie, make sure Henry goes upstairs with Jules and Molly.

content.text: Cassie and Sandra disperse. Nicole goes to the door. Sandra reappears from another entrance.
She grabs her glass and scurries away as Cassie reenters.

dialogue: Henry’s pooping in the bathroom downstairs.
Can we transfer him to the upstairs one?
OK, grab him when he comes out.
I’m putting the envelope here by the toaster.

content.text: Cassie hurries out of the room. The back door opens, Charlie enters in a whirl. He kisses Nicole on the lips, heading into a spare bedroom.
He dumps his bags on the floor. She watches through the doorway.
He reappears, squeezing past her into the kitchen.

dialogue: I got off the plane to a text-- But don’t tell anyone yet, it’s still a secret.

content.text: He goes straight to the refrigerator, passing the manila envelope next to the toaster. He turns to Nicole, unable to contain his excitement.

dialogue: Oh, Charlie, that’s so great. Congratulations!

content.text: She hugs him, truly happy for him.

dialogue: I’ll say it because you can’t, it’s the genius grant. You’re a genius.
I’m really happy for you. You deserve it--
It’s yours too. We did all of this together.
Well, thank you, but it’s yours, Charlie, enjoy it.

content.text: Charlie removes a roasted chicken from the refrigerator.

dialogue: It’s good money, and they parse it out over five years, but it means I can keep everyone in the theater company employed, pay my credit card debt and--
Of course I went instantly to, “it’s all down hill from here.” Now my first Broadway play HAS to fail--
We just started rehearsals again...I don’t know...
You always don’t know at this point and then it gets there--
Do I? Cause I don’t remember.
I know, but it’s true. It’ll be great.
OK. I hope you’re right. Everyone says, Hi.
Tell them Hi. I miss everyone.
Well, you’ll see them when you come back--
A MacArthur, Broadway, it’s so exciting. Congratulations, Charlie.

content.text: He picks at the chicken with his hands, licking his fingers. Nicole takes a breath, wanting to acknowledge the envelope sitting now to Charlie’s right and all that’s about to happen.
He starts off. She follows him into the other room.
He knocks on the bathroom door.

dialogue: Yay. Mom is giving me a present too.

content.text: Charlie reenters the kitchen. Nicole trailing.

dialogue: I don’t think we should reward him for pooping anymore.
I know, but he holds it in, it’s getting on a week...

content.text: Sandra pokes her head in.
Sandra kisses him on the lips. He lifts her up. Nicole watches impatiently.

dialogue: You didn’t respond to my last email!
Your emails are so articulate, I get intimidated!
Now, I’m going to lift YOU!

content.text: She wraps her arms around him and he pretends to be lifted.

dialogue: I’m going to go write you back now.

content.text: Sandra reluctantly leaves as Cassie enters.
Nicole and Cassie look at one another.

Charlie continues to eat (and mangle) his chicken. Cassie stands in front of him awkwardly. She collects her things, holds a pie tin, on top of a script. She’s red faced and blushing, and shaking from nerves.

dialogue: What kind of pie is that?
(long pause, as if trying to recall a line in a play)
I don’t know. No! It’s store bought. You know Joan’s on Third?
What? The store? Yeah! Jules and Molly love it.
Nicole says you’re doing a play?
I think you’d like it! It’s a great unproduced play by this really interesting British writer.
So you do an English accent?
Oh, what does that sound like?
Ya want a cup of tea, do ya?
Oh, thank you, missus. What is--

content.text: Charlie’s gaze goes down to the counter. The legal envelope lies there. Cassie sees him seeing this.

dialogue: It has my name on it.

content.text: He picks it up. She lunges forward and violently grabs it out of his hands. She hesitates and then formally hands it back to him.

dialogue: Oh Jesus, sorry. You’re served. Sorry.

content.text: Nicole reenters. She sees Charlie holding the envelope.

dialogue: Nothing. I don’t know. I can’t lie. You’re being served. You guys are getting divorced. I don’t know. I’m sorry.

content.text: She runs out of the room. Nicole looks at Charlie.

dialogue: I was going to warn you. So it didn’t become a thing.

content.text: Charlie stares at the envelope. And then:

dialogue: I feel like I’m in a dream.
We don’t have a marriage anymore.

content.text: Charlie looks up at her.

dialogue: I know you don’t want the disruption, but you don’t want to be married. Not really.
Well, what did you expect was going to happen?
I don’t know... I guess I didn’t think it through. But I thought we agreed--

content.text: Nicole gets out a bottle of whiskey and pours two drinks. She places one on the counter in front of him.

dialogue: We weren’t going to use lawyers.
I want a... I don’t know, I’m trying to say this as undramatically as possible. I want an ENTIRELY different kind of life.
Let’s wait until you finish this pilot and come back to New York and... Let’s figure it out there, at home. Together.
Nora is known for being really fair-
We don’t need to do this with envelopes and...
Yeah. She’s great. I feel like we could be friends with her.
Why do I feel like that won’t happen...
It’s a formality and you don’t have to respond right away.
Why...why did Cassie have a pie?
The pie was hers. The pie wasn’t part of it.
Yeah, I mean, what would the pie have to do with anything?
I don’t know, it somehow makes it worse.
Sorry. The pie was just a pie.
So, what... What do I do?

content.text: Charlie and Nicole lie in bed together on either side of Henry. Charlie is reading Stuart Little. They get to the end. Both Charlie and Nicole wipe tears from their eyes.

dialogue: I forgot it ended that way.
Yeah. Wow. Stuart really over- reacted, didn’t you think?
He was upset about his boat.

content.text: Charlie kisses Henry on the head.

dialogue: Dad, you go away-- Mom, you stay--
But you can come back and wake me up and read to me later, Daddy. OK?

content.text: Charlie gets up and walks outside the door. We STAY with Nicole and Henry.

dialogue: Will you come sleep in my bed later?

content.text: We CUT TO Charlie standing outside the door and for the first time shift to HIS perspective. He hears their whispers. A door squeak grabs Charlie’s attention. Sandra peeks out from her room.

Sandra shuts her door. He looks at the family photos on the hallway wall. Sandra younger on a TV show, being directed by Roberto, a handsome curly haired man with big glasses. Nicole and Cassie as kids.
A framed image from a New York Times article on Charlie and Nicole. They pose, looking great, standing apart on the stage of the theater. Titled: Scenes From A Marriage.
Nicole comes back out. She sees Charlie looking at the photo. She hesitates.

dialogue: He’s in a Mommy phase right now.

content.text: They both head down the stairs. Nicole sways for a second and clutches a bannister. Charlie takes her arm.

dialogue: Sorry, I think I drank too much wine--
Ha, yeah... I hope Henry didn’t notice.
Now that I’m a parent I realize my parents were probably drunk all the time with me.

content.text: He puts on his jacket, and leaves the room--

dialogue: There’s a new hotel over on Highland that’s supposedly not too expensive and pretty nice.
Again, that’s great about the MacArthur.

content.text: Charlie reappears clutching his bag.
They half-hug strangely, he holding his bag in one hand, she holding the legal envelope.
He heads for the door.
Nicole hands him the envelope with the divorce papers.
Charlie flips off all the lights in the room. Leaving Nicole in darkness.

Charlie sits across from a lawyer, 50’s, a strong, husky silver-haired man in a suit. This is Jay Marotta. The office is nothing like Nora’s -- sleek, corporate, tough. There are photos of Jay playing sports.
An associate, 30’s, Ted, a younger jock, sits at an adjacent table, taking notes.
Ted nods, knowingly.

dialogue: Here’s the fact Jack: I charge 950 dollars an hour, Ted is 400, so if you have a stupid question, call Ted.

content.text: Ted smiles at Charlie. Charlie looks sick.

dialogue: To start we’ll need a twenty-five thousand dollar retainer--
Oh, that’s more than I can--
And all your financials. We’ll need to do a forensic accounting.
Which runs anywhere from ten to twenty thousand dollars.
But if we can all agree right away, it shouldn’t get too bad, right?
You were married here, in LA?
Yes, because her mom and sister are out here and I’m not close with my family and so we just did it here...
And your son was born out here?
Yes, because again her family was out here and I’m not--
So you got married here, your kid was born here and she served you here?
Yeah. But we LIVED in New York.
We’re going to have to reshape the narrative.
If you’re serious about having your child in New York, this is what I would suggest, you take the kid, did you say his name is Fred--
I have a kid named Fred.
--you take Henry to New York with you right now. Then we file an action in New York. Make it a New York case--
We need to make an argument that you’re a New York based family.
Otherwise, you’ll probably never see your kid outside of LA again.
It’s very difficult to convince the courts to MOVE a kid. As soon as you let your wife and child leave New York, you made life very difficult for yourself.
Yeah, but as I said, we are a New York family, that’s just a fact. She’s here temporarily.
Then why do you think she served you out here?

content.text: Jay and the associate exchange a meaningful glance.

dialogue: I don’t...know. But, Henry wants to go back to New York, he tells me--
Don’t quote your kid. He’s just telling you what you want to hear. Trust me, he’s telling her the opposite.

content.text: Jay looks back at the papers.

dialogue: Exit Ghost. It’s the name of my theater company.
I don’t know. What have you seen?

content.text: Silence.

dialogue: Our production of Electra is moving to Broadway which is exciting--
We have to make sure that money is protected.
I mean, it’s theater, so it’s not a lot of money. I basically put whatever money I make back in the theater.
From Nicole? I’m not going to do that--
Does your wife’s family have money?
Her mother has some from her TV career and her father died--
We could say we don’t want her mother to see the kid, draw HER into the case.
In that instance, her mother could pay your legal fees too.
No. I’m very close to her mom. Nicole’s family has been my family- -
That’s going to change and I suggest you get used to that.
We should hire a private investigator--
We need to look for ways we can show she’s a bad mother.
Your wife do drugs or anything? Coke?
We’re not going to win if she’s a perfect mom.
She was addicted to Tums for a while.

content.text: Jay stares at him.

dialogue: It wasn’t nothing. She was up to a tube a day.
Have you noticed anyone following YOU?
Keep an eye out. California’s a no-fault state so even if you’re fucking around it wouldn’t matter, but, it doesn’t look good--
You need to be prepared for the fact that Nora’s going to portray you as a neglectful, absent, father.
You live in New York, consumed with your work, she and the kid are out here, struggling. Nora will use that strategy, I’m sure of it.
Listen, if we start from a place of reasonable and they start from a place of crazy when we settle, we’ll be somewhere between reasonable and crazy.
You know what people say, criminal lawyers see bad people at their best, divorce lawyers see good people at their worst.
You’ll end up hating me and Ted before it’s all over just because of what we represent in your life.

content.text: Charlie looks like he’ll pass out.

dialogue: Maybe I didn’t explain this well. We’re friendly, we’re fine, we’re just trying to figure this out--
So, tell me the story again, you came out to see your kid and she served you? What a bitch.
She’s not a bitch...thanks, but this isn’t...we’re doing it a different way. And I can’t even close afford this... I’ve got to get back to New York. I have a Broadway play in rehearsals--

content.text: Charlie stands.
Fade to Black.

Actors are mingling, stretching, in a mostly white room in midtown. Different color tape on the floor indicates the set. Various conversations are going on at once including Frank telling another anecdote from his younger days.

dialogue: She was Rosalind and I was Jaques. Nobody knew her then --
Do you think it’s OK that I’m doing the laughing fit that way. Nicole did it more like --
And I don’t want to imitate her--
Complete unknown. And I was the hot shit you know, young and very sexy with this great head of hair.
I just so appreciate that Charlie gave me this opportunity. Or maybe I should thank Nicole.
I heard Nicole’s pilot went to series so she’s staying in LA.
And they put Henry in school out there.
And you can’t do theater in LA.

content.text: They all laugh.

dialogue: Charlie said she and Henry are coming back to New York once she finishes filming her show.
She was never going to stay in New York. That was obvious.
She was probably planning this move all along.
When she sees an opportunity, believe me, she takes it.
Well, LA is nice. The space.
And you know it’s “The Park” and all that, and Joey Papp was directing, and she just glided on stage... we were cats in heat.

content.text: All of their attention eventually drifts toward Frank for the big finish.

dialogue: Miss future four time Oscar winner sucking my...

content.text: The door swings open and Charlie enters. He’s immediately swarmed by the costume designer and props guy who is showing him different items to approve.
Charlie puts his things down on a white folding table.

dialogue: Nobody come too close, I think I got Donna’s cold.

content.text: Terry and other actors approach him.

dialogue: Just a heads up, I’m waiting for a Skype call from Henry so I might have to step out--

content.text: Everyone very understandingly says “Of course.” “Say Hi from us” etc. Frank puts his arm around Charlie.

dialogue: What you’re going through now is going to be horrible. BUT it will be over.
Fuck as many people as you can right now. Women, men...

content.text: The Costume Designer, Donna, holds up a brown suit, hat, goggles and white gauze and a small Frankenstein outfit.

dialogue: You might need help wrapping some of the gauze, it needs to stay tight.
I’m confused. What scene is the Invisible Man outfit for?
No, that’s my Halloween costume. And the Frankenstein is for Henry.

content.text: All the actors surround him, approving of the outfits. “Aww!” “So cute!” “Frankenstein and the Invisible Man!”

dialogue: He’s coming here this weekend and we’re going to trick or treat in the Slope and whatever--
I made it more James Whale than Kenneth Branagh.

content.text: Charlie and Mary Ann duck into the hallway. The crew clocks this and makes knowing eye contact with one another.
Mary Ann hands him a stack of papers and an old scuffed up book.

dialogue: I typed up the notes from the last two rehearsals and here’s the blueprints--
--from the original layout of the Broadway theater--
Mary Ann, it’s too hard now...I just can’t be with anyone right now.
We did it when you were married, when we shouldn’t have done it. Now, that you’re not married, um, shouldn’t we be doing it?

content.text: His phone is ringing.

dialogue: Just make sure everything doesn’t go to hell here. I’m relying on you, OK?

content.text: He kisses her on the head. She flushes, rebuffed.

dialogue: I wish you’d accept generosity better.
(hesitates after this remark and answers the phone)

content.text: Charlie pushes open the fire exit doors--

dialogue: Hi, this is Nora Fanshaw, I represent your wife, Nicole Barber.
Do you have an attorney yet?
OK, then it’s OK for me to talk to you directly. OK?
I’m calling because we haven’t received a response to our filing.

content.text: The set designer, Agnes, opens the door to the stairwell and holds up two photos of stools. Charlie points at one of them. The designer nods.

dialogue: Yeah, I’ve been rehearsing this play and flying back and forth to LA--
You’re going to need to file your response.

content.text: Now she holds up two images of phones. An old style one from the 30’s and a rotary from the 70’s.

dialogue: Nicole said there was no rush.

content.text: He points at the rotary. She nods gratefully and hurries back inside.

dialogue: It’s been more than thirty days since you were served. By law you’re meant to respond within thirty days.
I didn’t like the first lawyer I met.
It says that very clearly on the document you were given. Did you read it?
But I thought that’s just what it says...we weren’t going to even do it with lawyers--

content.text: Charlie absent-mindedly fiddles with the X-Acto knife on his key chain, opening and closing it. Frank pokes his head in.

dialogue: Charlie, I’m thinking I shouldn’t tuck in the shirt?
(holding up a finger to say “hold on”)
Nicole said I could take my time--
--it keeps coming out during the love scene--
And we’ve let you take your time...
If you don’t file your response we’re going to file a request for default judgement against you.
You can’t just tuck it in tighter or get Donna to safety pin it?
I also have a thing about tucking in things--

content.text: Charlie indicates for Frank to come forward. He tucks it in for him.

dialogue: It’s a hold-over from childhood. Insecurities about my figure.

content.text: Frank looks at his reflection in the glass of a fire extinguisher. He does his “handsome” face. He pantomimes hugging someone. Charlie starts walking down the stairs.

dialogue: A default judgement. What does that mean?
We’ll be able to lay claim to whatever we want.
What do you mean? Whatever you want of what?
Your apartment, your things--well, everything you own.
She and I already discussed this, we don’t own that much stuff, she can have pretty much whatever she--
And it means, we’ll set the number for child support at its highest level and claim full custody of your child...
Full custody? I mean, that’s not even--

content.text: Charlie opens an Emergency Exit door and emerges into--
TIMES SQUARE
Chaotic city SOUNDS and vibrating video screens.

dialogue: This is what the law says.
Nicole’s not going to do that. I mean...she won’t.
No, Charlie, I represent Nicole and she’s aware of everything I’m saying to you.
I just spoke to her this morning.
Well, I spoke to her five minutes before I got on this call.

content.text: Silence.

dialogue: Um, OK, what do I do?
You need to get a lawyer and respond immediately. Nicole wants to do this amicably but you’re leaving us no other option, Charlie.
I’ll get a lawyer. Can I get a lawyer here?
That’s what all that honking is! No, you’ll have to come to LA and meet people in LA.
If you don’t respond in Los Angeles by Friday, you’ll leave us no choice.

content.text: LONG DISSOLVE TO:
A plane flies over palm trees and strip malls. We MOVE down to find: Charlie, dressed in a black coat and black jeans, wandering around aimlessly in a parking lot.
Charlie drives, fiddling with the air conditioning to no apparent success. He looks uncomfortable and hot. The sun suddenly blinds him through the windshield.

scene_info.location: SANDRA’S HOUSE, WEST HOLLYWOOD, LOS ANGELES

content.text: Henry comes running out. He wears shorts and high socks. Charlie opens his arms but doesn’t get a hug as Henry is on to other things.

dialogue: Me and Mommy are in the middle of a Super Secret Treasure Hunt--

content.text: Nicole follows. Her hair has been dyed blonde.

dialogue: I thought the plane landed at ten.

scene_info.location: SANDRA’S HOUSE, WEST HOLLYWOOD, LOS ANGELES

dialogue: He doesn’t like the breeze on his legs--
Why don’t we ever do a treasure hunt?
I’m not done searching for my money!
Can I talk to you for a minute? Henry, can you wait a minute--
Just one bit of talking alone and then I’ll be right there--

content.text: He walks Nicole over away from the car and Henry.

dialogue: I got a call from your lawyer. She said you’d take everything and custody and everything if I didn’t respond.
Yeah, but she’s saying things I don’t think you mean--
It’s better if we just let the lawyers do this--

scene_info.location: SANDRA’S HOUSE, WEST HOLLYWOOD, LOS ANGELES

dialogue: We said we’d figure this out together.

content.text: Henry starts running back to the house.

dialogue: Henry, we need to get going--
Have you gotten a lawyer yet?
I don’t want to go now.
That’s what I’m here to do.

content.text: Charlie opens the car door.

dialogue: Come on, Henry, I’m in a rush--
And I looked Nora up. She’s fancy. We...you can’t afford her.
She said she’d make it work--
Why did you start a treasure hunt or whatever so close to my arrival?
You were late, we were killing time.
We can finish the treasure hunt later. Go with Daddy now, it’ll be FUN.
I’ll have a present for you when you get back as a reward--

scene_info.location: SANDRA’S HOUSE, WEST HOLLYWOOD, LOS ANGELES

dialogue: He’s not going to the dentist.

content.text: Henry grabs hold of his Mom.
Charlie gently takes Henry’s arm.
Henry yanks it back. Charlie pulls again on Henry who is clutching his Mom.
This tug of war feels ridiculous and Charlie lets go.
Nicole looks at the car-seat in the back of the car.
Charlie leans in. The car-seat isn’t connected to anything. Charlie and Nicole, both crouched closely together in the back seat, share a small laugh.

dialogue: I asked the rental company to install it.
I think they can’t for liability reasons--
Do you know how these things-

scene_info.location: SANDRA’S HOUSE, WEST HOLLYWOOD, LOS ANGELES

content.text: Henry itches his nose as he watches his parents struggle with the booster seat.

dialogue: There should be a clip thing, a thing to clip on to.

content.text: Charlie gets out, he’s sweating and his hand is bleeding.

dialogue: It’s my time with you. I just flew three thousand miles.
Henry, get in the fucking car!

content.text: Henry laughs uncomfortably and then reluctantly climbs in.

dialogue: I’m sorry, but Jesus, get in the fucking car.

content.text: Charlie drives. He sucks on his hand which is bleeding looks at all the billboards on the strip. Henry sits in the back.

dialogue: How do you spell Lego Bionicles?
That’s two words. What does Lego start with?
Don’t you want to learn it?
No, it’s on the box anyway.
E. You know, everyone at the theater says Hi.
A “ggg” sound. Are you excited for Halloween?
I’m going to go as a store-bought ninja.
But we agreed, I had Donna make you a Frankenstein.
I don’t want to be a Frankenstein anymore.
Are you sure, maybe just look at it? It’s awesome. We’ll be Frankenstein and the Invisible Man!
Mom bought me a ninja costume which is better because it costs more.
Technically, the Frankenstein costs more when you factor in Donna’s time and the materials--
The cousins are also going to be ninjas.
But Henry, we went through all this trouble--

content.text: Charlie lowers the window and stretches his arm out to push the button to get the ticket, but he’s not pulled in close enough. He has to open the door, unbuckle himself, and step out to push it.
A wide white space flanked by windows. Charlie, still sucking on his hand, carries two travel bags and he and Henry, having checked in, head toward the elevator bank.

dialogue: (in the middle of a previous conversation)
...and so I’m not comfortable leaving the bags in a car where I’ve given the key to someone I don’t know--
It’s an office building so you’ve been to places like this before.

content.text: Charlie approaches the receptionist.

dialogue: A lot of fish look the same.

content.text: The receptionist looks up.

dialogue: I’m Charlie Barber, I have a one thirty with Dan Cohen.
Oh, hi. Where’s your little man?
I don’t have it this time. I keep my skeletons at my mom’s.

content.text: Charlie looks at Henry strangely and back at the receptionist. She scrolls on her computer and frowns.

dialogue: OK... Oh, OK... I’m sorry, we tried to reach you, Mr. Cohen wanted me to apologize. He can’t see you because apparently your wife already met with him on the 7th of August about representation...
But she hired somebody else, uh, Nora...
Fanshaw? But unfortunately because she consulted with Mr. Cohen already, he’s legally barred from representing you.

content.text: She rises and leads Henry over to the tank.

dialogue: It happens all the time. If you have a ticket I can validate your parking.

content.text: Charlie searches for his ticket. He gets blood from his hand on the loose bills and receipts in his pocket.

dialogue: It’s common that people meet with as many lawyers as possible so that their spouse has limited options.
I don’t think she would have done it deliberately.
Did you go to a lot of offices with your mom?

content.text: In harsh sunlight, Charlie heads for his parked car, on the phone, pulling a rolling bag and hauling a duffel. Henry trails behind him, carrying Charlie’s lap-top bag and eating a hamburger over a paper bag.

dialogue: I don’t think anyone would have stealed the bags, Daddy.
I need somebody TODAY. If I don’t respond by tomorrow, she said I could lose custody? I didn’t know who else to call... There’s got to be someone she didn’t meet.
She’d kill me if she knew we were talking.
I know. I really appreciate it.

scene_info.location: SANDRA’S HOUSE, BATHROOM, LOS ANGELES. INTERCUT

content.text: Sandra, her head in a scarf, and tinted blue glasses on, runs the shower to drown out her conversation and talks in a whisper. She flips through an old address book.

dialogue: OK, I have a name for you. Bert Spitz. He was the entertainment lawyer at Roberto’s agency, and for years, he negotiated all of Robbie’s Dynasty and Falcon Crest deals. He kind of got pushed into retirement a few years ago and he went into family law.
It’s a double “O”. What sound is that?
Blood. You’re getting good at reading.

content.text: Charlie and Henry approach the car in the parking lot.

dialogue: I called him and he can see you today at 4.
And he should be more affordable.

content.text: Charlie opens the back door and indicates for Henry to go in. Henry drops his burger on the pavement.
Sandra now lies on the tile floor looking under the bathroom door to see if someone is listening.

scene_info.location: SANDRA’S HOUSE, BATHROOM, LOS ANGELES. INTERCUT

dialogue: We never had this conversation, Charlie-bird.

content.text: Sandra hangs up.

dialogue: Because you made us carry your bags into the restaurant, I dropped it.

content.text: Charlie picks up the burger and wipes it off.

dialogue: It’s fine, get in the car.
Why did you take me today if you couldn’t hang out with me?
Because I’ve been away and want to see you.

content.text: A cramped parking lot in the back of an old run-down building on Hollywood Boulevard. Charlie helps Henry out of the back seat.

dialogue: Getting a divorce with a kid can be one of the hardest things you’ll ever do. It’s like a death without a body.

content.text: A man, late 60’s, in slacks and a tweed jacket, takes a pill from a container and swallows it with a glass of water. This is Bert Spitz. A grizzled cat wheezes in a corner on a stained pillow.

dialogue: I know, personally I’ve been there four different times.
I’ve been married four times. Three divorces. This last one will stick God willing.

content.text: Charlie nods as Bert sits across from him.

dialogue: That’s why I graduated into family law. To help people survive this painful time.

Here’s how I see it: If we get bogged down in who did this and that and “I don’t want to pay the two dollars” it’ll just cost you more money and time and emotional stress, and you’ll probably end up with the same result anyway.
Right. I mean, I agree with that philosophy. She does too, I’m sure.
And I always go with the truth wherever that takes us. Most people in this business make up the truth to get to where they need to go.
You’re just transactions to them. I like to think of you as people.
And not just you, her too.
It can be an ugly process. But I believe it also doesn’t have to be terrible.
I’m glad to hear you say that. Um, I’d love to keep expenses down as much as possible.
Of course you do. I charge 450 an hour and I’ll need a ten thousand dollar retainer to start.
Maybe this is a stupid question, but is there any way to do this on a budget?
I’ll see if I can get an advance on the Broadway transfer...
And keep in mind, you’ll have to pay for her lawyer.
Or at least part of her. It doesn’t make sense, does it? The reason you’re doing this is because you love your kid and in doing so you’re draining money from your kid’s education.

content.text: Bert shuffles through the papers in front of him.

dialogue: We’ll have to respond right away.
Your son is in school out here?
Temporarily. We agreed. Her pilot went to series and I wanted to accommodate her as she’s often felt we do things on my terms.
Be a better husband in divorce.
I guess something like that. But we live in New York.
With your kid in school here, the court may see it otherwise.
No no no, we don’t want to go to court, the California courts are a disaster -- it’s just how we have to think about it.
I’m not sure these are my glasses.
Where are you living when you’re out here?
I’m in a hotel right now--
You just said we weren’t going to go to court.
Of course, of course. We prepare to go to court hoping that we don’t go to court.
You should get a place in LA. And get a place NEAR her. That will look better for custody reasons.
She’s in West Hollywood. That’ll be expensive. I guess I could rent our New York apartment.
Don’t rent it, you need to continue to prove New York residence--
(not sure what he’s going to do)
And of course getting a place in LA, doesn’t make it look like you all live in New York, does it?
I recommend you try to spend as much time with your child as possible. Many people fight to get the time and then they don’t even use it. They just want to win.

content.text: Bert leaves his office and disappears down a hallway. Charlie follows.

dialogue: This shouldn’t be that complicated, right? I mean, we’re a New York family. I think it’s all pretty straight-forward. Right?

content.text: Charlie finds Bert in a kitchen area. The old cat following them. Bert opens an old fridge and takes out some of kind of meat and rice in a tupperware container.

dialogue: I hope so, yes. I see no reason-- you both love your son, you respect each other--why this shouldn’t be relatively pain-free?

content.text: Bert gathers plastic silverware from a drawer and heads through another doorway into an outer office/waiting area. Charlie hesitates and follows.
Henry looks at a magazine on the floor with Bert’s associate, Nell, 30’s.

dialogue: I think you have my glasses--

content.text: She takes off hers and they swap. She nods.

dialogue: And I was reading this magazine.

content.text: Henry pets the old cat.

dialogue: I wouldn’t expect too much from that cat.

content.text: Charlie follows Bert back to the kitchen.

dialogue: I want you to know that eventually this will all be over and whatever we win or lose, it’ll be the two of you having to figure this out together.
Thank you. You’re the first person in this process who has spoken to me like a human.

content.text: Bert, tears in his eyes, hugs Charlie.

dialogue: You remind me of myself, on my second marriage.

content.text: Henry runs in and hugs Nicole. Charlie stands in the doorway, he holds the Frankenstein Halloween costume. The place is decorated warmly for the holiday and delicious- looking food is being prepared by a house-keeper.

dialogue: Did you have fun with Daddy?
Do you want to try on your ninja costume? It’s on your bed!

content.text: Henry runs upstairs.

dialogue: You know I had Donna build him this whole Frankenstein thing with the plugs and --
The cousins are ninjas so he wanted to do that too.
But he and I had decided together--
I can’t make him be Frankenstein.
I’m not asking you to. But maybe you could help me out a little. I’ll leave the Frankenstein here and maybe you can nudge him in that direction--
What’s the...did you dye your hair again? Is that for your show?
No, this is me. It was this way when I saw you before.
I know, but I didn’t say anything then.
No, I guess...it’s fine. Is it shorter? I prefer it long, but...
You seem...I don’t know like something is--

content.text: Charlie peers over her shoulder again at the warm living room. Nicole stands as a sort of barrier.

dialogue: OK, I’m going to check in at the hotel, but should be able to get to you guys by five, five thirty. We’ll go trick or treating from there--
Um, we’re going to go to Cassie’s in Pasadena.
Yeah, she and Sam moved a couple of months ago.
OK. I don’t really know Pasadena. I’ll figure it out. What’s the address? I’ll text Sam.
And because my mom is looking forward to this and Cassie and Sam are--
Wait until you see MY costume.
--so I think we should probably do separate Halloweens--
But if you’re OK with it, then shouldn’t they be OK with it--
Let’s just do it this way this time. OK?
Do you not want me there?
It’ll be nice for him, he’ll get two Halloweens.
What am I going to do with him for second Halloween? Walk around Sunset Boulevard?
Maybe the hotel has something? Or you can drive to another neighborhood?

content.text: Charlie, wrapped in gauze, in a brown suit sleeps slumped over on the couch. The TV is on. The hat in his lap. A beer and a crinkled candy wrapper from the mini-bar on the coffee table.
The doorbell rings. He startles awake.
He puts on the hat, checks himself in the mirror, straightens his goggles and gauze and opens the door.

Nicole is dressed in a peach suit and her hair in a sort of pompadour a la David Bowie. Henry dawdles behind her, in the hallway. His ninja mask is askew and his costume hanging partly off. Charlie, ignoring Nicole, greets Henry.
Charlie adjusts his goggles.

dialogue: Sweetheart, don’t forget your jacket. It’s getting colder.

content.text: Henry passes by both of them and into the room. Charlie parts the gauze over his mouth so he can talk easier.

dialogue: You ready to go back out?

content.text: She hands Charlie Henry’s backpack.

dialogue: Some of his men and Bear Bear are in there-- You can keep this Bear Bear because I got another one--
Does he know that there are two Bear Bears?
I have LA Bear Bear and New York Bear Bear--

content.text: Charlie regards Nicole.

dialogue: OK, bye Henry. Have a great Halloween with Daddy.

content.text: Charlie nods coldly and closes the door.
Henry turns his plastic jack o’ lantern over and dumps all his candy on the floor. He lies down and starts sorting it.

dialogue: Go pee and then we’re going back out!
GO pee and then we’re going to go drive to Halloween!

content.text: Charlie, wiping moisture off the windshield, cranes his neck, trying to see out the glass.

dialogue: If we were in New York we could be walking.
But I like that we’re sitting right now. I like to sit.
That’s true, Los Angeles does have sitting going for it.
I think that’s why I like Los Angeles better.
And because I like my friends here better.
That’s not true. What about Horatio and Poppy and--
Horatio doesn’t like me anymore and I don’t like Poppy. Here I have Axel. Axel is hilarious. And my family is here. Besides you.

content.text: Cars rush by. The Invisible Man and a ninja in a parka hold hands looking for an opening to cross.
They dart across the street.
They trudge up a steep curvy street behind Sunset.
They stand outside a house. They ring and wait. Nobody answers.
They approach the convenience store counter. Henry’s mask is coming off at this point.
The seventeen year old clerk looks around and hands them some junk.
Charlie drives. Henry is falling asleep in the backseat.
They both exhaustedly enter. Henry turns his plastic jack o’ lantern over and a couple of things trickle out. Something lands with a thud. Charlie picks it up.
Henry goes into the bathroom to pee. Charlie gets a beer.

dialogue: I’m going to have to go back to New York on Monday.

content.text: Henry comes back out.
Henry goes back in and does. Comes back out.
Henry returns to the bathroom. Charlie hears the water run and then he reappears.

dialogue: Did you hear me? I have to go back to New York.

content.text: Henry gathers some of his toys.

dialogue: Aaah, watch out... BSSSHH! “I’m falling.” “I’ll catch you.” BOOOM. “You didn’t catch me.”
I have to work. You know my play is opening on Broadway.
Is it because you don’t want to be near mom?
No-- You know, like we’ve talked about, we’ve decided not to be together no matter where we are. But we both want to be with you.
But you’re not near me if you’re in New York.
Well, we all still live in New York.
Yeah. But I go to school here.
Just for right now. Like that time we were in Copenhagen for my play. Remember all those kids in buckets?
I like my school here and Mom says we can stay here if we want.

content.text: Charlie freezes.

dialogue: What do you mean...She said that?

content.text: CUT TO: Henry is asleep in the king size bed in Charlie’s
room with his bear as a pillow. Charlie turns out the light and adjusts the covers. He watches Henry for a beat and kisses him on the cheek.
Charlie steps out onto the small concrete balcony attached to his room. He’s on the phone.
We see now: Nicole stands out by a pool on the phone. She’s still dressed as David Bowie. Agents, the ex-husband and wife producers from her show, actors, all in costume, mingle inside and out.

dialogue: Yes. Henry says you’re moving here???

content.text: Charlie clicks his portable X-Acto knife in and out.

dialogue: I want to talk about it as us.
Let’s just get in a room, YOU and ME, that’s what we always said we’d do.
My lawyers wouldn’t let me sign anything.
It’s not up to them. It’s up to us. It’s OUR divorce.
They say I could later sue them for malpractice.
Yes! What the fuck is going on?
I read your fucking emails, CHARLIE. I read them all.
You are a FUCKING LIAR. You fucked Mary Ann.
It was after I was sleeping on the couch.

content.text: Some guests glance over at Nicole who is now shouting.

dialogue: And all this bullshit about working on us or whatever, you know what-- I HAVE been working, I’ve BEEN DOING THE WORK. ALONE.
How did you read my emails?
I HACKED INTO YOUR ACCOUNT YOU DUMB FUCK.

About a week ago. So don’t give me this shit about being surprised about LA. Surprise! I have opinions. Surprise! I want things that aren’t what you want because SURPRISE YOU WERE FUCKING ANOTHER LADY.
How do you even know how to do something like that?
I think you’re conflating two different things. Mary Ann has nothing to do with LA.
I’m conflating, motherfucker. Watch me conflate!

content.text: She hangs up and visibly stamps her foot.

dialogue: Did you just stamp your foot?
I don’t think I’ve ever done that before. I’m sorry I’m just so ANGRY.

content.text: She’s handed a drink by Pablo, the tatted grip from her show. He wears a tight black T-shirt with a ratty flannel thrown over it and black jeans.

dialogue: You look like you needed one.
You know the Japanese are making really interesting tequila right now.
What are you so angry about?
Ugh, my fucking ex-husband. I spend so much time feeling guilty, but he’s so self-absorbed it’s pointless. It’s a game I’m playing with myself.
Oh, hey, Pablo. We met at the--

content.text: They’re making out in the front seat.

dialogue: Here’s what I want you to only do, OK?
I want you to finger me.
That’s all we’re going to do, OK? Just fingering. I’m changing my whole fucking life.

content.text: Fade to Black.

dialogue: Nicole and Charlie’s son, Henry, was born here in Los Angeles and currently attends Laurel Elementary in Laurel Canyon--

content.text: CLOSE on Nicole.

dialogue: --and Nicole works in Hollywood on her show while also maintaining a full schedule as a mother with classes of swim, art, gym and music as well as play groups.

content.text: And then CUT TO Charlie, in a dark wool suit, who sweats.

dialogue: Nicole is Henry's primary custodial parent and to the extent that Charlie would like to exercise his custodial time, he should be making efforts to visit Henry here in California.

content.text: And now INTERCUT between their two faces as if they’re having a conversation, though neither of them opens their mouth. They both listen to their representatives, sometimes with emotion, other times anger, disbelief, and self-consciousness. They occasionally look at their hands or jot down a note.

dialogue: Nora, you seem to be ignoring the fact that they lived in New York for ten years--

My client worked in New York, for several years--that’s true. But Nicole was born and bred right here in LA. She and Charlie would come here most holidays and summers to spend time with her family who all live here. She and Charlie were married here, would you like to see the photos?

content.text: We CUT WIDE.
The room has big windows with views of other surrounding glass offices.
Nicole sits next to Nora who looks amazing in an expensive, fitted power suit and heels. Behind them sits, Amir, Nora’s associate.

dialogue: I don’t need to see the photos-- Although I’m sure they both look beautiful--

content.text: Bert grins at Charlie who seems to be sweating through his wool blazer. They sit across the wide table. Bert’s associate Nell behind them in a chair by the window.

dialogue: It’s my client’s expectation that after this TV show is completed, the parties will move back to New York where they currently keep an apartment--

And it’s my understanding that Charlie PROMISED Nicole that they would spend more time in LA during the marriage but because of Charlie’s insistence that his work keep them in New York, Nicole ended up staying much longer than she ever anticipated. In fact, a few years ago, Charlie was offered a residency at the Geffen Playhouse that would have taken his work and family to LA for a year and he turned it down knowing full well that this was Nicole’s desire.
