He wanted to maintain consistency for his family and his child.
Was this the same consistency he wanted to maintain when they went to Copenhagen for six months so he could direct a play?

content.text: An assistant has her head in the door trying to get Amir’s attention.

dialogue: So, while I understand that CHARLIE lives in New York and when it’s convenient for his work schedule, flies out here to see his son--
He flies out here every chance he gets at great expense--
I don’t see any reason you can’t be out here full-time.

content.text: Amir acknowledges the anxious assistant and interrupts.

dialogue: Oh... Sorry. Do we want to contemplate lunch--I’ll order now so it’ll come when we’re all hungry?

content.text: Charlie is taken aback, unsure how to process this question. He shakes his head.

dialogue: You’ll love it, just really yummy salads and sandwiches.

content.text: Amir passes out menus. Orders are made, Bert specifying no butter or cream. It gets to Charlie, he’s unsure.

dialogue: Charlie will have the greek salad.
But with olive oil and lemon instead of the greek dressing, and I’ll get the Chinese chicken salad.

content.text: Charlie nods, satisfied. Amir writes down the orders and hands them to an associate who exits. Nora gets up to pour herself and Nicole more coffee.

dialogue: Congratulations, Charlie, on your grant, Nicole told me.

content.text: He tussles Charlie’s hair. Everyone laughs awkwardly. Charlie blushes. Nicole smiles sweetly, sensing his discomfort. Nora raises a mug, offering Charlie.

dialogue: I told Nicole, I LOVED your play. You are one smart cookie. I’d love to get inside your brain!
There was that one moment when you smell the toast.
Smell! It was literally my favorite thing I saw that year. Truly genius.
I was sorry to hear it closed on Broadway.

content.text: Charlie looks at Bert, like why bring that up?
Charlie nods. Nora places the coffee in front of Charlie.

dialogue: Now, whenever Charlie is in LA, Nicole, of course, agrees that it will best for Henry to see each parent equally--
It’s nice out here, Charlie. You should give it a chance.
Yeah, and the space -- you can’t beat it.

I love it too, but all of our personal feelings about the two cities aside, we don’t share your assertion that the couple is an LA based family. It was very clearly their deal that they would go back to New York after Nicole finished her show.
I’m not aware of any deal.
I didn’t get it in writing.
Charlie, is this like the deal you made that you and Nicole would spend more time in LA during the marriage?
We didn’t have a deal. It was something we discussed...but...
So, it’s a deal when it’s something you want, but it’s a discussion when Nicole wants it?

content.text: Silence.

dialogue: Nora, is there a spare office, where Charlie and I could sidebar?

content.text: A small, windowless, bare impersonal room with a table, a phone, some left-out coffee cups and a plate with crumbs.

dialogue: And you’re in a bind because you’ve shown that you’re willing to fly out here and rent an apartment to see your son--
You told me to do that!
And I’m doing that because I want to see my kid. Not to set a precedent.
Yes, but unfortunately you are setting a precedent. And a judge may look at it that way.
What’s the alternative? I stay in New York and never come out here?
No, because then it will look to the court like you don’t care about seeing your son.
Court or no court, stop saying court and then never court!
Well, the way this is going, we might have to go to court.
Are you aware how maddening you sound?
I am. And I know it seems unfair. But imagine if you were a poor mother abandoned by her husband who refuses to pay anything. That’s what the system is trying to protect people from.

content.text: Charlie nods.

dialogue: Listen, if I were representing you--
Right, no, of course. I don’t see a judge moving this child from LA-- I think we try to settle today--
No, Bert... just NO. I mean, we have to win this?
Remember, the win is what’s best for Henry. And if you guys go to court, he’ll get pulled into it.
If he stays out here and I stay in New York, that’s just, then I won’t, I’ll never get to really be his parent again.
Maybe you move here. You heard what Amir said about the space.
Fuck the space, Bert. FUCK THE SPACE.

I’ll do whatever you want me to do, but this is my advice. I’ve seen these things go on and on and the burden of these battles is immeasurable. I had a client get colon cancer and die before he and his wife came to agreement.
What about filing in New York?
It’s too late and even if you did, I don’t think it would matter. They’re being reasonable financially. You’re lucky they’re not asking for half of your grant money--
She wouldn’t do that. She knows, I put all that money back in my theater.
The actors and crew all rely on that money, they have families and- - A court would never agree with this, right?
Whether they do or not, it’ll cost you half your grant money anyway to go to court and prove it.

content.text: Charlie deflates.

dialogue: But you didn’t commit any crime.
If we give on LA right now and try to make the best deal possible, I think we can get her to give on some other fronts.
There are no other fronts. This is the thing.
He needs to know that I fought for him.
I should never have let her come out here with Henry.
If it wasn’t LA and New York it would be something else. You’d be fighting over a house or school district or... It’s like the joke about the woman at the hairdresser who’s going to Rome--
A woman is at her hairdresser’s and she says, “Oh, I’m going to Rome on holiday” and the hairdresser says--

content.text: Charlie stares at the clock on the wall.

dialogue: “What airline are you taking?” And she says, “Al Italia.” And he says, “Oh that’s the worst airline I’ve--”

content.text: He continues the joke as Charlie observes the second hand moving around the circle. Finally:

dialogue: I’m sorry, Bert, but am I paying for this joke?

content.text: Bert hesitates.

dialogue: No matter what happens here, it’s temporary. He’s growing up, he’s going to have opinions on the subject. Time is on your side, Charlie. Maybe he’ll do college on the East Coast.

content.text: CUT TO: Henry’s face. He’s talking animatedly about how
much money he has in his piggybank.

dialogue: I have my quarters and dimes at Daddy’s, but I’m keeping my dollars and my one twenty with you, OK?

content.text: Charlie watches him.
Nicole’s face is on the computer screen in front of Henry. He’s doing Face Time with her.
The place is small and mostly bare with furniture that came with it.
CLOSE: A bill from Bert’s firm for 25 thousand dollars. Charlie sits at a table with a stack of bills, legal letters, and a checkbook open. He hesitates.

dialogue: Did you lose power where you are?
It’s back on now. There are rolling blackouts in the hills but now the gate won’t close.

content.text: Nicole stands outside in the dark. The gate is wide open. Charlie appears from the shadows holding Henry’s hand.
Henry runs and hugs his mom.

dialogue: Can I look at my room?

content.text: Henry runs inside. They remain outside.

dialogue: I’m sorry I made you come out--
You don’t want your gate open.
There should be a panel or something either inside or--

content.text: She stands in the threshold, blocking his path. She points toward a white box amongst trees in the yard.
He steps over some bushes and inspects the alarm system.

dialogue: I mean, from what I can see.
Yeah, I have to find a haircutter.
Do you want me to cut it?

content.text: Charlie, shirtless, a towel around his shoulders, sits very still on a chair. Nicole cuts his hair. The porch light illuminating.
Charlie does.
CLOSE on the scissors snipping across his shut eyes.

scene_info.location: NICOLE’S NEW PLACE. ECHO PARK, LA

content.text: Nicole carries the sleeping Henry. They both smile at the sweetness. Henry stirs.

dialogue: He’s out. Maybe he should stay here tonight--

content.text: She nods and hands him to Charlie.
CUT TO: Charlie and a tired Henry pull on the gate. Nicole
helps, dragging from the other side. It starts to close. They yank it shut, closing her in and them out. We CUT QUICKLY between them both just as it closes. We stay with her.
Fade to Black.
The sound of a couple loudly arguing in Spanish.

A man and woman are shouting at each other. The lawyers trying to separate them. Various benches are filled with the other divorcing couples, men and women sitting apart from one another with their individual representatives.
In their midst, Nora and Nicole sit on a bench in the wide, dingy hallway. Amir sorts through documents nearby.

dialogue: I think we’re mostly finished. Bert and I hammered out ninety- percent of the details, there’s a couple minor things hanging that should be easy and then the judge will make your divorce official.
I hear the tracking for your show is off the chain--
Oh, I don’t even know what that means, but good I guess--
I made sure the date of separation came AFTER the pilot pick-up to protect that money--

content.text: She follows Nora’s gaze to Jay Marotta who marches down the hallway, conferring with Charlie.

dialogue: It’s not television. It’s not a wise judge played by a great character actor. These are just people open to manipulation like anyone else. You think it’s justice, but it’s not.
What do you mean? Where’s Bert?
It means everything we’ve agreed upon is now off the table.

content.text: Jay and Charlie take a bench a ways away.  Jay says Hi to some other lawyers.

dialogue: Not with Jay Marotta representing him. This is a street fight now. And I’m going to have to ask for things we wouldn’t normally ask for. We’ll need as much leverage as possible to negotiate with.

content.text: Nora rises with a pinched smile--
--and greets Jay.
Nicole looks over at Charlie who doesn’t meet her eye.
The low hum of a copier machine and periodic mouse-clicks from a computer.

Jay speaks in front of the judge who clearly has a bad cold. Charlie sits at the end of the table with Ted, the associate. Nicole is at the corresponding end of an adjacent table next to Nora and Amir.

dialogue: Ten years ago, Charlie takes a risk when he first hires Nicole as an actress in his play in New York City.
He’s a well regarded, up and coming director of the avant garde and she’s known as the girl in that college sex movie who takes her top off.
My client will not be slut- shamed for an artistic choice.

Ten years on and many prestigious theater roles later, she’s become an actress of great credibility. And because of this credibility, she’s offered a lead roll on a major television show. This new opportunity in her life is thanks to Charlie. Your honor, I don’t see why we should be paying any support money at this point. In fact, Charlie should be entitled to half of her TV salary, present and future earnings on the show.

content.text: Nora takes a moment.

dialogue: Charlie has just received the enormous sum of six hundred and fifty thousand dollars in the form of a MacArthur grant for the theater work he has conducted during the marriage.

Of which he gets in 125 thousand installments over five years, money that is used to employ actors and crew members and to pay back debts he’s accumulated with his theater company that stars his wife.

By Jay’s same logic, this is work that Nicole contributed to in numerous ways. Not only did she give up a lucrative and successful career in movies to perform in his little theater, she also supplied Charlie with a loan early on to help out.
She lent her name to the marquee and was the principle reason people came to the theater.
That may have been true ten years ago--
She, in turn, helped establish Charlie’s reputation.

content.text: Charlie looks over at Nicole. She looks down.

dialogue: Over the next ten years she was subsequently offered parts in movies, TV shows, most of which she turned down at Charlie’s bequest to be a mother and to act in his plays. Now, while we’re willing to be flexible on support we contend that half of Charlie’s grant money should be split between the parties.

content.text: Charlie looks at Jay.

dialogue: I don’t see how you can claim that she gets half a grant dedicated to his genius.
He became a genius during the course of the marriage.
Charlie, himself, upon hearing he received the prize, told Nicole it belonged to her too.
That’s something people say when they win awards.
No, he was implying what was true: his genius was an intangible asset built during the marriage.

content.text: Charlie and Nicole both stare at the floor.

dialogue: Nora, I like how you refer to Charlie’s theater as a ramshackled downtown dump when you’re arguing custody, but when you want more money, Charlie’s a big rich genius Broadway director. You can’t have it both ways.

Why not? And whether you think it’s fair or not, Jay, the first monetary installment from the MacArthur grant was then put in a joint marital account and thus became community property so this and any further installments should be split between the parties.

content.text: Jay whispers to Charlie.

dialogue: Fuck. You shouldn’t have put that money in the joint account.
There’s not going to be anything left anyway, I’m using it all to divorce her...

content.text: Jay turns back to Nora.

dialogue: Nora, I have to say your account of this marriage takes place in an alternate reality. By suddenly MOVING to LA, and insisting on an LA residence, Nicole is withholding Henry, alienating him from his father. This has turned Charlie’s world upside down. It amounts to an ambush.
Withholding, Jay? Really? Alienating. Those are fighting words and it is simply false and does nothing to further our settlement. Your recap of this situation is outrageous.
And although California is, without doubt, a no-fault state, it does bear mentioning in the accurate recap of this situation that Charlie had had extramarital affairs--

content.text: Nora turns and stares at Charlie.

dialogue: Do you really want me to go there?
Let’s go there. Nicole has admitted to HACKING Charlie’s computer and reading his emails.

content.text: Nora turns to Nicole who shrugs. Jay stands.

dialogue: Which if proven is a felony. And Nora, I don’t think you’ll be happy if I start to ask Nicole about her alcohol consumption in the evenings--

She confided in Charlie one night recently, having just carried Henry to bed, that she was having trouble standing while walking down the staircase. From what I understand this was not an isolated event. You let me know, Nora, otherwise we’ll go there as needed.

content.text: Jay sits back down. Nicole stares at Charlie who looks humiliated.

dialogue: Charlie, can I ask you: How can you expect to have more time with Henry when you don’t exercise the time you have AND exercise it responsibly.

On a recent visit to Los Angeles, after failing to text, call or communicate in any way, shape or form, Charlie finally arrived two hours late to pick up Henry at Nicole’s mother’s house. At that point the car seat which he assured Nicole had been professionally installed was clearly not even belted in, just sitting on the back seat.

content.text: Jay turns to Charlie.

dialogue: You have to buckle the seat in, man, it’s the law.
I know that. I thought the car rental place did it.
They can’t do it, it’s a liability--
I know that NOW! Once we discovered that, we fixed it.

content.text: The judge wipes his runny nose and interrupts--

dialogue: Counsel, you can see my courtroom is full and there are people who don’t have the resources your clients have. And I’m fairly certain you haven’t exhausted in good faith the arguments in the case of this child. In the meantime, we’ll keep the status quo. This remains an LA family for the time being.

content.text: Charlie’s face drops.

dialogue: I took over this department recently and am still becoming acquainted with the cases so I’m going to appoint an expert evaluator who knows much more about young children than I do. Once the evaluation is done we’ll modify the orders where necessary.

content.text: CUT TO: A door opens revealing Nicole. She smiles
politely.
Charlie, somewhat formally, ushers her in.

dialogue: He’s with Cassie and her kids at Laser Tag.
I have unfiltered tap water, beer and some juice boxes.

content.text: He goes into the kitchen. She looks at his rental place. It makes her sad.

dialogue: You don’t have anything on the walls.
I don’t have anything to put on them except Henry’s art which is being framed.
I can give you some things, you know until you get some stuff... How about that great picture of Henry on the Staten Island Ferry--
Oh, right, I guess I am.
I guess you can cut me out?
Oh, I’m going to have to leave a day early to go to New York on the 22nd so I was wondering if I could take Henry that Friday--
The 22nd? So, that’s the 21st? We have plans actually. We’re going to this thing at LACMA with the cousins--

content.text: He reappears and hands her a juice box.

dialogue: But could you change it so I can take him--
It’s only that night. He’s looking forward to it.
It’s my night, Charlie, we negotiated it.
No, I’m just asking you to be flexible--
I AM flexible. You come in and out and I adjust based on your schedule. This one night we happen to have to have tickets to a thing. I mean...
It’s not only this one night, but fine...

content.text: She opens the straw, and uses it to puncture the hole and sips the drink.

dialogue: Henry’s teacher wants to meet with us.
Can you respond to the email so we can set a time?
I understand. They just want to rule out everything, you know, with his reading.
I think he’s just over-anxious. I think he wants it so much.
I know, he quits too easily if things aren’t easy for him. You know, he’s like us, he’s stubborn.
They said he’s off the charts in math.
He’s still a lousy Monopoly player because he tries to save all his money.

content.text: Charlie laughs. Nicole smiles.

dialogue: So... I thought we should talk.
I feel like maybe things have gone too far.
I mean, my mom has taken out a loan against the house to help me pay Nora-
You pay thirty percent of Nora.
Well, I’m going broke too if that’s any help. I’ve just agreed to direct two shitty plays and we can forget putting anything away for Henry’s college.
It’s just that...up until now we’ve been able to keep Henry at least somewhat removed. And this will change that.
And we have to protect him.
Nora says the evaluator will come into our homes. She’ll interview Henry in addition to us, our family, friends, enemies... And then she’ll observe us with him, how we are as parents.
I know! I feel like if anyone observed me on any given day as a mom, I’d never get custody.
I know. I feel the same way.
Right. So, maybe we can figure something out between us--
You’ll remember I said this to you at the beginning.
I know you did, but these are different circumstances--
Mm hm. Anyway... Shall we try this?

content.text: There’s a long silence. They both laugh.

dialogue: I don’t know how to start...
Do you understand why I want to stay in LA?
Well, that’s not...Charlie, that’s not a useful way for us to start--
You don’t remember promising that we could do time out here?

We discussed things. We were married, we said things. We talked about moving to Europe, about getting a sideboard or what do you call it, a credenza, to fill that empty space behind the couch. We never did any of it.
And you turned down that residency at the Geffen that would have brought us here and--
It wasn’t something I wanted. We had a great theater company and a great life where we were.
You call that a great life.
Me discovering you’re fucking Mary Ann--
Don’t pretend you’re not capable of deception. You left Ben for ME.
I don’t mean we had a great marriage. I mean, life in Brooklyn... Professionally. I don’t know. Honestly I never considered anything different.
Well, that’s the problem isn’t it? I was your wife, you should have considered my happiness too.
Come on! You WERE happy. You’ve just decided you weren’t now--
So, OK, let’s... I work here now. My family is here.
And I agreed to put Henry in school here because your show went to series. I did that KNOWING that when you were done shooting, he would come back to New York...
Honey, we never said that. That might have been your assumption, but we never expressly said that...
I don’t know when we said it, but we said it!
We said it that time on the phone--
I thought...that if Henry was happy out here and my show continued, that we might do LA for a while.
I was not privy to that thought process.
The only reason we didn’t live here was because you can’t imagine desires other than your own unless they’re forced on you.
OK, you wish you hadn’t married me, you wish you’d had a different life. But this is what happened.
Nora says there’s no coming back from this.
Fuck Nora. I hate fucking Nora telling me I always lived in LA even though I never lived in LA. How could you have her say those things about me?
Jay said them about me too!
Let’s both agree both of our lawyers have said shitty stuff about both of us--
You pulled the rug out from under me and you’re putting me through hell--
You put me through hell DURING the marriage!
Is that what that was? Hell?
And now you're going to put Henry through this horrible thing so you can yet again get what you want.
It’s not what I want...I mean, it’s what I want, but it’s what was...WAS...what’s best for him.
I was wondering when you’d get around to Henry and what HE actually wants.
No, YOU fuck off. If you listened to your son, or anyone, he’d tell you he’d rather live here.
Stop putting your feelings about me onto Henry.
He tells me he likes it here better.
He tells you because he knows it’s what you want to HEAR!
He tells me you’re on the phone all the time. You don’t even play with him.
Because I’m going through a divorce in LA and trying to direct a play in New York.
You’re fighting for something you don’t even WANT.
Which closed because I wasn’t THERE! That was a HUGE opportunity for me. For the theater. And I let everyone down.
You’re being so much like your father.
DO NOT compare me to my father.
I didn’t compare you. I said you were acting like him.
You’re exactly like your mother! Everything you complain about her, you’re doing. You’re suffocating Henry.
First of all, I love my mother, she was a great mother!
I’m just repeating what you’ve told me--
Secondly, how dare you compare my mothering to my mother? I might be like my father, but I’m NOT like my mother.

You ARE! And you’re like my father. You’re also like MY mother. You’re all the bad things about all of these people. But mostly your mother. When we would lie in bed together, sometimes I would look at you and see HER and just feel so GROSS.
I felt repulsed when you touched me.
You’re a slob. I made all the beds, closed all the cabinets, picked up after you like an infant--
The thought of having sex with you makes me want to peel my skin off.

You’ll never be happy. In LA or anywhere. You’ll think you found some better, opposite guy than me and in a few years you’ll rebel against him because you need to have your VOICE. But you don’t WANT a voice. You just want to fucking complain about not having a VOICE.
I think of being married to you and that woman is a stranger to me.
You’ve regressed. You’ve gone back to your life before you met me. It’s pathetic.
People used to say to me that you were too selfish to be a great artist. I used to defend you. But they’re absolutely right.
All your best acting is behind you. You’re back to being a HACK.
You gaslighted me. You’re a fucking villain.
You want to present yourself as a victim because it’s a good legal strategy, FINE. But you and I both know you CHOSE this life. You wanted it until you didn’t.

content.text: Nicole is silent.

dialogue: You USED me so you could get out of LA.
You did and then you BLAMED me for it. You always made me aware of what I was doing wrong, how I was falling short.
So you had to fuck someone else? How could you?
You shouldn’t be upset that I fucked her, you should be upset that I had a laugh with her.
No! But she didn’t hate me. You hated me.
You hated ME. You fucked someone we worked with.
You stopped having sex with me in the last year. I never cheated on you.

But there’s so much I could have done. I was a director in my 20’s who came from nothing and was suddenly on the cover of fucking Time Out New York. I was hot shit—-and I wanted to fuck EVERYBODY and I didn’t. And I loved you and didn’t want to lose you...and I’m in my twenties and I didn’t want to lose that too. And you wanted SO much so fast...I didn’t even want to get married...and fuck it, there’s so much I DIDN’T do.

content.text: Nicole stamps her feet and shakes her fists like a child having a tantrum.

dialogue: I can’t believe I have to know you FOREVER!

content.text: Charlie raises his arm and punches the wall. The cheap dry- wall cracks and chips.

dialogue: Are you kidding? I wanted to be married. I’d ALREADY LOST.
You didn’t love me as much as I loved you.
What does that have to do with LA?

content.text: Nicole stares at him, incredulous.

dialogue: You’re so merged with your own selfishness that you don’t even identify it as selfishness anymore. YOU’RE SUCH A DICK.
Every day I wake up and hope you’re dead-- Dead like--

content.text: And then Charlie starts crying.

dialogue: If I could guarantee Henry would be OK, I’d hope you get an illness and then get hit by a car and DIE.

content.text: He sinks down, weeping. All this vitriol has taken its toll. Nicole watches, taken aback. She walks over and gently puts her hand on his shoulder. He shakes and cries.
Finally, he looks up at her.

dialogue: Try the chair by the window...

content.text: Charlie gets a delivery of rental plates, glasses, furniture, plants. He stands on his balcony directing the delivery men.
Charlie set-decorates his rental. He Skypes with Agnes, his set designer from the theater. Holding out the computer to show her the apartment.
He buys a stack of board games with Henry.
He and Henry get Henry’s drawings at framer.
They hang the art-work.

dialogue: Why do we have so many plants all of a sudden?
We’ll have to return some of this stuff so don’t get too used to it.
My mom is the last person to turn into a plant on her show.
I find plants kind of scary.
Hey, tomorrow this woman is going to come and visit us and be with us while we eat dinner.
No, why...does Mommy have a boyfriend?
I don’t know. Why is someone watching us eat dinner?
I know, it’s weird. It’s just something we have to do which has to do with Mommy and me figuring out everything...and how we’re going to be and...you know?

content.text: Charlie and Henry lie down on the floor against the blank wall and Charlie starts reading to him.
We STAY on Nicole who sits facing an unseen evaluator.

dialogue: Oh... No. You mean coming from me? No. Not coming from him either...
Yes, actually. Well, not prison. Jail. But it was deliberate.
I was demonstrating as part of a Grandmothers for Peace rally. I was with my mom, but she didn’t go to jail.
Somehow she avoided that part. But I did.
Do you use drugs or alcohol?
How much alcohol do you drink?
I don’t know. Glass of wine with dinner. Sometimes more?
Well, sometimes, a few...  I sometimes split a bottle of wine with someone?
OK. Who do you split it with?
I mean, if I’m having dinner with someone and we order a bottle of wine.
You know, like if you’re at a restaurant and you say, “Should we go by the glass or get a bottle?”
Sometimes! Sometimes I go by the glass. You know, it depends...
Do you mean drugs ever? I have done drugs. In college. I don’t do it regularly.
Anything since you’ve been a mother?
Pot a few times. Coke once at a party. But Henry wasn’t with me.

content.text: Silence.

dialogue: What would you say are your strengths as a parent?

I listen. I play. I put in the time. I love taking care of him, watching him grow up... Sometimes it’s true what they say about it goes so fast, but sometimes it’s not. Sometimes it goes too slow, honestly...
I’m too precise. I care too much.
You know what, he can be an asshole and I can get really pissed off. I’ll call him on being an asshole and--
I’m going to stop you there.

content.text: Nora stands up from behind the female associate who is doing the practice interview with Nicole. We’re in Nora’s office.

dialogue: Don’t ever say that. People don’t accept a mother who drinks too much wine and yells at her child and calls him an asshole. I get it. I do it too.

content.text: While she talks she also texts and addresses emails on her phone.

dialogue: We can accept an imperfect Dad. Let’s face it, the idea of a good father was only invented like 30 years ago. Before that fathers were expected to be silent and absent and unreliable and selfish and we can all say that we want them to be different but on some basic level we ACCEPT them, we LOVE them for their fallibilities. But people absolutely DON’T accept those same failings in mothers.

We don't accept it structurally and we don't accept it spiritually because the basis of our Judeo- Christian Whatever is Mary Mother of Jesus and she’s PERFECT. She’s a virgin who gives birth, unwaveringly supports her child, and holds his dead body when he’s gone. But the Dad isn’t there. He didn’t even do the fucking because God’s in heaven. God is the father and God didn't show up so you have to be perfect and Charlie can be a fuck up and it doesn't matter. You’ll always be held to a different, higher standard and it’s FUCKED up, but that’s the way it is.

content.text: Charlie is cooking an elaborate dinner. The bell rings. He takes a deep breath.
He glances into Henry’s room. He’s playing by himself on the floor.
He walks through the set-decorated living room which looks relatively homey, full of warmth and board games and pictures of Charlie and Henry.
Charlie opens the door. A diminutive woman with frizzy hair is staring at the door across the hall. She startles, turns around and smiles and puts out her hand.

dialogue: I think I rang the wrong bell. Nancy Katz.
Hi, I’m Charlie Barber. Nancy, can I get you anything?
Oh, I’m easy. A glass of water?

content.text: Kitchen. Charlie opens up a cabinet. Plates. He opens another cabinet. Pots. A third cabinet. Empty. Finally he finds glasses in a low cupboard. He glances back at the evaluator who waits patiently.
Charlie and Nancy take their drinks to the dining room table.

dialogue: Sure. What’s a day like for the two of you here?
Well, if he has school, I take him there, of course and pick him up, assuming I can do both.
What prevents you from picking him up?
Um, you know, work. I’m preparing a play I’m directing in a few months.
Kasimir and Karoline by Odon von Horvath? We’re doing it at the Barrow in New York.
So, you have to be away?
Yes. Recently, since Nicole has been working on this show in LA, I come back and forth a lot.
It is. And expensive. I’ll try to take him with me some of the time, but Nicole doesn’t like for him to fly so much.
That can be hard on a child. All that recycled air.
Some parents won't take their kids to a restaurant because of these super bugs.
I notice on one visit to Los Angeles, you came on a Sunday and left on a Thursday. Why not stay for a weekend?
Oh...on that time, I had tech for Electra back in New York.
I don’t know what tech is.
It’s the technical part of the production. You figure out the lights and--
And what’s a weekend day like?
Monday is our day off in theater--
Well, out here he has basketball on Saturday at 12, 11, I’m sorry and so we go there.
And then afterwards, maybe we’ll get lunch somewhere and then if there’s a movie to see...
He does. His coach, um, Rick says he’s a good dribbler and I’ve seen that...
Ron. I’m sorry. His coach’s name is Ron. Rick’s his dentist in New York.

content.text: The evaluator writes something in her book.

dialogue: Well, you know our home home was...is in New York. That’s where we live and--
New York is a long way from here.
We like it because we can walk.

content.text: Charlie nods.
CUT TO: HENRY’S ROOM
Henry plays on the floor. The evaluator sits in a chair.

dialogue: What’s your favorite part about it?

content.text: Charlie enters and hands Henry a plate with cut-up apple. Henry takes it.

dialogue: You’re welcome. But you’re getting really good at it.

content.text: Charlie exits.

dialogue: What do you and your Dad like to do together?
When I’m at my Dad’s we sometimes watch a movie or build a Lego or something. My Dad’s a great Lego builder.

content.text: Nancy smiles.
HALLWAY
Charlie listening at the door, smiles.

dialogue: At home, I have most of my toys and-

content.text: Charlie bristles at the word “home” used to describe Nicole’s.
HENRY’S ROOM

dialogue: --there’s a pool and I have a tree- house and jungle gym. We play lots of games. We have Super Secret Treasure Hunt which is really fun.

content.text: CUT TO: KITCHEN
Charlie is making ground meat and potatoes and spinach. He has a lot of burners going at once, making a mess.

dialogue: Sweetheart, do you want to help me set the table.
Just come in here and grab a plate and--

content.text: HENRY’S ROOM
Henry plays with his men on the floor. The evaluator sits in a chair nearby.
Henry gets off his chair and goes into--
KITCHEN

dialogue: Why are you being like this?
If I ask you to help out, help out.
What are the green things? There aren’t green things in special meal.
I don’t want to eat anything it touched.
It doesn’t change the taste of anything.
I might want to be a vegetarian. Mom’s a vegetarian.
Well, then you should like garnish. It’s all garnish, vegetarianism.

content.text: Charlie looks over. Nancy stands, watching, in the threshold of the kitchen.
She returns her water to the sink.
DINING AREA
Charlie and Henry eat. Nancy sits with them.

dialogue: You sure you don’t want anything?

content.text: They eat in silence. The evaluator observing.

dialogue: Do the thing with the knife.

content.text: Silence.

dialogue: What’s the thing with the knife?
No...it’s dumb. I have a small knife on my keychain. Which is only for adults. I do a thing with it sometimes...
You said I could get a knife.
A jack-knife, yeah. When you’re older.

content.text: Charlie watches the evaluator’s face closely, trying to discern something, anything.
LIVING ROOM
Charlie and Henry do his homework. Henry is sounding out a word.

dialogue: Honey, stop guessing. You’re so close, stay with it.
Ugh, I don’t want to do it.
I don’t want to do it. Can I do the iPad?
No. Just look, what’s the first letter?
It’s a T. What sound does T make.
Right and then just do the rest of it.
No! You have “Tuh” and “ime.” What is that?

content.text: Henry takes a piece of tape and puts it on his mouth.
He looks at the evaluator. She nods. Henry rolls over onto his front, playing dead.

dialogue: You’ll see, honey, one day it’s just going to click and you’ll be able to read everything.
I need a break. Can I play in my room?

content.text: Charlie tries to kiss him on lips. Henry gives him his head. Charlie kisses the top of his head. Henry runs out.
Nancy is looking at the crack in the wall from Charlie’s punch. Charlie clocks this. Silence.

dialogue: Do you ever observe married people?

content.text: Silence.

dialogue: The knife thing is, I carry this knife on my keychain which his mother got me actually--

content.text: He takes out his key-ring and shows her the X-Acto knife.

dialogue: --and I’d do this thing for his mom--

content.text: He clicks open the knife.

dialogue: Where I pretend to cut myself, but I retract the blade--

content.text: He pantomimes cutting his arm.

dialogue: But I don’t do it with him...

content.text: The evaluator stares at Charlie with horror. Charlie hesitates and follows her gaze. Dark red blood streams down his arm.
It’s really bleeding. He covers it with his hand, the blood spreading between his fingers.

dialogue: Yeah, I must not have retracted the blade all the way.

content.text: Blood is getting over everything. He lowers the sleeve on his oxford shirt to cover the wound. Red blots immediately soak through the cotton.

dialogue: (smiles at her and crosses his legs)
What else can I tell you?

content.text: Silence.

dialogue: Well, I’ll leave you guys for tonight.
I’ll be in touch if I have further questions.

content.text: She stands and gathers her things while Charlie grabs her coat from a chair and holds it out to her, his left shirt arm growing crimson. She takes it, trying to avoid the blood.
She climbs into her coat, Charlie nominally helping out with his good arm, and moves toward the door.
She tries to open the door, but it’s locked. She turns a bolt and another latch but it still won’t open.

Charlie rushes over and undoes the bolt. She tries to get out of the way of the blood, while he reaches his long arms around her to do this, putting them both in a strangely intimate proximity. He pulls and it won’t open.
He does the latch and finally it opens.
She flushes and smiles awkwardly and slips out, closing the door behind her.

Charlie runs into the kitchen, swaying, leaning against the wall for support. His shirt is now soaked in blood. He rolls up his sleeve, and runs cold water on his arm. He winces. Watery blood fills up the pots and pans in the sink mixing with whatever bits of remaining food.

He finds a small box of band-aids in the cupboard and opens about seven of them and tries to cover up the wound. But it’s still really bleeding. He wraps his arm in paper towels, sweat now sliding down his face and soaking his armpits. He drops to the kitchen floor and lies down on his back in exhaustion and pain.
Two small bare feet step over him and pad over to the refrigerator.
Charlie rolls over onto his arm, hiding it from Henry. The sound of milk being poured into a glass. Then the feet re- approach and step back over Charlie. Little drips of milk whiten the floor.

dialogue: Yeah, she thought we were great.

content.text: Fade to Black.

scene_info.location: NICOLE’S NEW PLACE. ECHO PARK, LA

content.text: Cassie, Sandra and Nicole sing “You Could Drive a Person Crazy” from the musical, Company -- The tight harmonies are sung a capella, and there are dance moves to go along with it.
The group of people watching includes kids and an agent, cast and crew from her show and family -- it’s a housewarming party.
(The house looks very different from the home she shared with Charlie. More color, more patterns, more hippy-dippy, more lamps, more her. It’s how she likes it.)
They finish their song and everyone applauds, kind of to be polite, but also because it was seriously, strangely great.
Nora pops the cork on a big bottle of Cristal.

Nicole is getting food together for the guests, pulling saran wrap off platters. She leaves cabinet doors open which she maneuvers around. Kids run through the room playing. Guests enter to grab drinks, etc.
Nora makes a heart symbol with her hands and leaps up on the kitchen counter, swinging her feet and drinking champagne like a teenager.

dialogue: So, because Charlie dropped his claim to New York, we’re mostly done. Jay’s lost interest and Ted, his associate, is doing the paper work.
And we’re not taking any money, right?
We withdrew the claim for the MacArthur, which I think we could have gotten by the way, and they’re not asking for any of the show.
OK, good. Thank you for everything, Nora
And when Charlie’s in LA, I got the custody breakdown to be 55/45, so you’ll have Henry one extra day every two weeks...
I thought we made it equal.
I tweaked it at the last minute. I just didn’t want him to be able to say he got 50/50.

content.text: CLOSE on Nicole writing her signature. She uses the last name (her maiden name) Ryder.
Nicole sits at her kitchen table in LA.

scene_info.location: CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S APARTMENT, NEW YORK

content.text: CLOSE on Charlie writing his signature.
Charlie sits on the floor of his half-empty apartment.
An ASPCA guy approaches him smiling.

dialogue: You look like a guy who really cares about animals--

content.text: He watches a mother and father with a young baby in the stroller.
Charlie sits in a barber’s chair getting a haircut.
Charlie enters the same restaurant we saw everyone at for the closing night party so many months before.
He sees Mary Ann and Terry and a couple of other actors. A piano player, actors singing, performing.
He joins his old group. The gang is happy to see him. He opens a tab at the bar for everyone.
They all sit at a booth, having been drinking for a while now.

dialogue: ...and the couch was technically hers pre-marriage, but, I mean, it was OUR couch, it’s not like I was going to BUY another couch but then when it comes time to split, it’s suddenly HER couch and I have no couch and-- I’m sitting on the floor is the short version.
I’m sorry. This is all so self- pitying and boring.
Oh, no, no, sounds really tough.
No, it’s all stupid. I’m sorry.

content.text: The piano player plays the opening notes of a song. Charlie recognizes it.
He gets up and walks to the piano.
People know who he is, and are intrigued to see what he’s going to do.
Sings “Being Alive” from Company. It’s sloppy, but surprisingly emotional and comes from a deep place. And in the end is beautiful.
Fade to Black.

scene_info.location: SANDRA’S HOUSE, WEST HOLLYWOOD, LOS ANGELES

content.text: Charlie gets out of his rental car.
He knocks on the back door. No answer. He apprehensively opens the screen door to the kitchen. Food is on the stove. Music plays. It’s warm and welcoming.
But Charlie remains in the threshold.
He hears laughter from the other rooms. And then Henry shouting excitedly.
Suddenly Carter runs, breathlessly, into the kitchen. He clutches a ray gun.
He sees Charlie and hesitates.

dialogue: Hi. Sorry, the door was open.

content.text: Carter puts his finger up to his lips.

scene_info.location: SANDRA’S HOUSE, WEST HOLLYWOOD, LOS ANGELES

content.text: The electronic sound of something bad happening. Carter’s been hit in laser tag. Sandra runs in holding a gun.
She hesitates when she sees Charlie.
She comes forward and hugs him. It isn’t cold particularly, but it isn’t what it was. Carter extends his hand.
Silence. Then Henry enters.
Henry hugs Charlie. Charlie smiles at everyone awkwardly.
CUT TO: Charlie, Sandra and Carter talk at the dining room
table. Nicole arrives from filming her show. Carter rises, they kiss.

dialogue: Good. Donny’s dead now. I shot the scene where he merges with the ficus.

content.text: Charlie grins.

scene_info.location: SANDRA’S HOUSE, WEST HOLLYWOOD, LOS ANGELES

content.text: Charlie nods, a bit stunned.

dialogue: I love it. Now I know what you were so obsessed with all the time.

content.text: Everyone clomps upstairs. Charlie follows.

dialogue: I didn’t really get a costume together.
I don’t need to be anything.
At least a ghost! I’ll get you a sheet--

content.text: Sandra and Carter hurry into different rooms, getting ready. Nicole enters into the bathroom.

dialogue: We should leave soon! I’m saying that as much for me as anyone else.
I wanted to tell you, I took a residency at UCLA. I’m going to direct two plays in rep at Red Cat.

content.text: Nicole reenters holding a sheet.

scene_info.location: SANDRA’S HOUSE, WEST HOLLYWOOD, LOS ANGELES

dialogue: So, I’ll be here for a while.

content.text: But something strikes her as sad about it too.

Sandra calls her for help with her costume. Nicole hands Charlie the sheet and goes into the next room. Charlie, alone, inspects the sheet. He notices the photos on the wall have been swapped out with different ones. He hears:

dialogue: “Charlie is...in...cr...” -- something -- ”neat and I re-ly on him to keep things in or-der. He’s energy con...” -- I don’t know what that word is --

content.text: Charlie drifts towards Henry’s room.
Henry, legs dangling off his bed, reads from a crinkled loose leaf paper.

dialogue: You’re getting so good at reading.
“He doesn’t look in the mirror too of-ten. He cries eas-ily in movies...”

content.text: Charlie hesitates and sits next to Henry on the bed.

scene_info.location: SANDRA’S HOUSE, WEST HOLLYWOOD, LOS ANGELES

dialogue: That means sew, like a hole--
“--a shirt. He rarely gets def- eated
(which I fell...feel like I al-ways do)
. Charlie takes all of my moods stead-ily, he doesn’t give in to them or make me feel bad about them. He’s a great dress-er, he never looks em--” I don’t know this one...

content.text: Nicole appears in the doorway.

dialogue: “--embarrassing wh-ich is hard for a man.” You read it now...

content.text: He hands it to Charlie. Charlie reads:

dialogue: “He loves being a dad, he loves all the things you’re supposed to hate, like the tantrums, the waking up at night-- He disappears into his own world. He and Henry are alike in that way. He can tell people they have food in their teeth or on their face in a way that doesn’t make them feel bad. Charlie is self-made -- his parents -- I only met them once -- but he told me there was--

scene_info.location: SANDRA’S HOUSE, WEST HOLLYWOOD, LOS ANGELES

dialogue: He’s brilliant at creating family out of whoever is around. With the theatre company he cast a spell that made everyone feel included. No one, not even an intern was unimportant.”
Like a helper. But who isn’t paid.
They’re young. They’re learning... I don’t know, maybe if they do a good job, they get paid later?

“He could remember all the inside jokes. He’s extremely organized and thorough. He’s very clear about what he wants unlike me who can’t always tell. I fell in love with him two seconds after I saw him and I’ll never stop loving him...”

content.text: Charlie hesitates. He swallows. He’s crying.

dialogue: “...even though it doesn’t make sense anymore.”

content.text: Henry, Nicole, Carter, Sandra are dressed as the Beatles from Sgt. Pepper. Carter is Paul. Henry is Ringo. Nicole is John. Sandra is George. Charlie’s a ghost. They’re joined by Cassie and Sam and their kids, also dressed up.
The kids run from house to house trick-or-treating.
The adults linger and talk casually.

Henry, exhausted, is having trouble keeping his eyes open. Nicole regards him. Charlie, his sheet on his arm now, is saying goodbye to the family as Sandra takes off with Cassie and Sam. He shakes Carter’s hand, it’s friendly. Nicole hesitates then approaches Charlie.

dialogue: We were going to bring him to dinner, but he’s wiped out. Do you want to take him?
I’ll drop him back in the morning?
Yeah, just text when you’re up and we’ll figure it out.
You’re going to go with your Dad, OK?

content.text: The boy wraps his arms around his Dad’s neck and Charlie lifts him.
She kisses Henry’s face which rests on Charlie’s shoulder and for a moment all three of their heads are nestled close together. Then Nicole releases.
Charlie, holding Henry, advances toward his parked car. Nicole watches.
Charlie hesitates as Nicole hurries after him. She kneels down in the middle of the street.
CLOSE: Charlie’s laces spill out on the pavement.
She tugs on one which he’s stepping on. She taps his calf.
He lifts up his foot so she can retrieve the lace.
She ties his sneaker. Charlie watches.
She nods. He hikes Henry up tighter in his arms and continues toward his car. Nicole and Carter get in their parked Subaru in the foreground.
The Subaru drives toward us and off-camera and then reappears heading away from us now. As they pass Charlie and Henry, an arm waves out the window. Charlie raises his hand back.
Nicole’s car heads into the distance. Charlie stops at his rental and digs for the keys in his pocket. Henry holds on.
All of them, Nicole and Charlie and Henry, are now recessed into the landscape. The light is waning. We hold on the wide tableau of the LA street and finally cut to black.
End.
